text: mothers who separate from their partners are recovering faster from the collapse in income that many women experience after a marital split research reveals today the institute for social and economic research at essex university found the financial effects of separation used to be catastrophic for mothers and children between and the average decline in a mothers income was after splitting from a partner comparing spending power in the years before and after the breakup but between and the figure was the researchers measured the income of the mothers household after adjusting for the number of adults and children living in it prof stephen jenkins the institutes director and the studys author said separating mothers and their children are still experiencing far worse financial circumstances than their departing partners between and the separating fathers enjoyed a rise in net income in the year after the split between and this declined slightly to but the mothers are recovering faster from financial meltdown as they are more likely to get a job and are more likely to qualify for support from the state to make the job worth doing separating mothers were helped by rising rates of employment for women during the s and early s said jenkins these were given a particular stimulus by the introduction of the working families tax credit in which both increased the incentives for those in workless families to find a job and helped to make work pay the study based on annual interviews with households found most women with children never totally recovered from the financial effects of the split five years on their incomes were on average still below presplit levels those who had a job in the year after the split and kept it for the next five years came close to restoring their income to presplit levels those who did not have a job and did not find a new partner remained much worse off jenkins said the mothers financial recovery might be regarded as good news but added there remain large gaps on average between the shortterm income losses of separating husbands and of separating women this is despite the improvement in the circumstances of women with children the average shortterm income loss for childless separating women has remained fairly constant over the last years gender remains a good predictor of whether an adults income rises or falls after experiencing a marital split dr paul dornan the head of policy and research for the child poverty action group said some have argued the tax credit system somehow incentivises parents to live apart but that argument is hollow mothers are worse off after relationship breakdown

text: it strikes me after reading about the survey of womens working patterns before and after childbirth the baby blues study finds a third of mothers slip down the career ladder february that none of the writers has addressed a key problem the attitudes of many women themselves i am the mother of a fourmonthold baby and a professional researcher i am going back to fulltime work in a month with my son going to nursery onsite i have encountered shock from women of all ages they generally assume i am only going back parttime and ask why i want to return fulltime i can go through several reasons such as i want to i love my job i like being financially independent but the only one that washes is when i say im the breadwinner my choice is only accepted when its perceived to be a nochoice situation until these entrenched social attitudes are changed women will be forced off the career ladder without any help from government or men dr jane mooretaylor chesham buckinghamshire until the age of i enjoyed in many ways sexual and economic equality with men i had my own house a decent job and a fairly autonomous life by i was broody desperate even to have a baby and acquired four males a son husband and twins in that order keeping my brain cells intact and a foothold in the outside world has proved very tricky i have been plunged into social and psychological conditions of mothering that are actually worse than my mother encountered in the s social mobility has meant no grandparents to call on and no extended family networks for support lack of funding for nannies the tyranny of the pm school gate and the isolation of the modern nuclear family means that in this socalled postfeminist era i have little more choice than my own mother my marriage my sense of self and my career have all had to take place in the narrow margins that motherhood permit bev gold cambridge rosie boycott the world is still organised to meet the wishes of men february is right to remind us that universal childcare is key to closing the gender gap but shes painting a toobleak picture daycare trust the national campaign for universal childcare believes that this government has done a lot with free early education for three and fouryearolds childcare subsidies and much better parental pay and leave to support working parents the vision of a scandinavianstyle society with free childcare is within our grasp and the government is on the right track it just needs to go further and faster alison garnham daycare trust slipping down the career ladder is only a disadvantage if you consider a career to be more valuable worthwhile and fulfilling than raising a family i work parttime and raise the kids my wife has a very successful career and pays most of the bills i used to spend to lucrative hours a day staring at a computer screen this afternoon i took my kids to a coffee shop for a chat after school sorted out a fight over toys and helped my son prepare for a test i also heard my sevenyearold tell her first dirty joke i could find more challenging work but i know that the hours would be longer and the stress would be greater and then when the kids fight i might not keep my cool there seems to be a false assumption that mothers want a successful career maybe some want a close family and a lowstress job jake stone burnaby british columbia canada despite strong laws prohibiting discrimination against pregnant women and new mothers many women are forced to return to lowerstatus jobs particularly when returning parttime the caring divide is enormous women have weeks maternity leave the first six weeks on pay men have two weeks on this is the widest gap of any european country the proposal to allow mothers to transfer part of their maternity leave to fathers is not enough until men are given reasonable and properly paid paternity leave nothing will change failure to provide this is arguably discrimination against men it also disadvantages many women who are left holding the baby camilla palmer london by equating parttime with secondrate rosie boycott inadvertently perpetuates the myth that only fulltime jobs can offer career fulfilment with the benefit of a flexible working environment and support from my partner family and a great nursery i am training parttime as a barrister i am passionate about my job but i dont want to work fulltime the time i spend with my daughter and the time i spend at work fulfil me in different ways and i wouldnt want to compromise on either we must stop categorising parttime work as a poor alternative and strive to make it fairly paid and valued anna edmundson london further to the limitations imposed on womens professional development by childrearing there is the impact on their mental health do we adequately prepare and support women as they encounter the change in social status that motherhood brings this is more important than ever given the marked difference between the opportunities available to women before becoming mothers and the limited options afterwards annabel friedlein welwyn hertfordshire rosie boycott describes her sister returning to work when the youngest of her five children started preschool we are told that she was married to an architect but not what she does valery ryan london

text: the most shocking aspect of this weeks figures showing how far women slip down the career ladder after having a baby is that they come as a shock to anybody since any parent realises immediately after the birth of their first child that they have just taken part in a job creation exercise that will provide fulltime work for at least the next years it is still astonishing that children are completely ignored in career planning and this is at a time when we are all too eager for these same children to become career minded as early as possible with increasing emphasis on links between education and work after the recent work week in my fouryearolds reception class in which parents put themselves up for probing questions about their careers such as do you have a cat in the office my daughter announced that she wanted to be two things when she grows up on tuesdays and wednesdays she would be a doctor the rest of the week she would be a cowgirl i so admired her early desire for worklife balance that i felt i couldnt really sit her down and go into the practical difficulties of flexible working but maybe i should have done because i wish someone had done it to me at my girls secondary school highflying doctors designers or engineers would come in from time to time to give talks i remember being particularly inspired by an international lawyer who talked about lots of foreign travel status intellectual stimulation and general glamour she didnt once mention what happened if the nanny was off sick good feminists that we then were we probably wouldnt have listened anyway why on earth should womens career ambitions and decisions be made on any basis different from mens well i now have two very good reasons why the fouryearold has an older sister and i am still confused about why when they feature so centrally in my career decisions now they were never taken into consideration when it came to careers advice in january ed balls was telling schools to offer impartial careers guidance to pupils rather than promoting hairdressing courses to girls and construction apprenticeships to boys he wanted more young women being encouraged and supported to have a career in engineering and more young men being encouraged to have a career in childcare he said of course girls have just as much right to information about engineering courses as boys and of course you shouldnt make assumptions about their future life plans nearly a fifth of women never have children after all but that still leaves the vast majority who do and the vast majority of men too and yet this fact has somehow become unmentionable often right up until a new mum returns to work and has to scrabble around with personnel officers trying to cobble together a parttime career until school hours mean she has to give up altogether encouraging young women to aspire to be engineers is admirable and important but it is also only fair to address the fact that project managing a north sea oilrig is tricky with toddlers and that goes for fathers of young children too i can see why it might stick in the craw of businesses or professions when recruiting to think that their future employees may occasionally have other things on their minds than devotion to their employers but they are deluded equally deluded are those who think worklife balance means a few beanbags scattered around the office in my experience most women and many men do at some point make career decisions based on their domestic circumstances wouldnt it be a lot easier for everyone nonparents included if their workplace acknowledged this then women and men could openly plan careers that recognised that they might want to see their kids occasionally and advice on childcare options could become as important a part of a personnel officers job as advice on the pension package until then ill be advising the fouryearold to be a cowgirl full time and that could mean we all miss out on a particularly adaptable doctor

text: woman is a biological distinction femininity is that group of personality traits women are traditionally expected to exhibit feminism is a movement which challenges these gender stereotypes and combats discrimination against women if youre a man obviously you cannot be a woman at least not without major and quite painful surgical intervention as a man you can be feminine or like most people exhibit a mix of feminine and masculine characteristics likewise progressive men should be allowed to regard themselves as feminists despite my aversion to the limiting effects of labels i would certainly define my views on gender issues as being feminist cath elliotts article last week highlighted the controversy about whether men can be classed as feminists although she expressed her personal indifference to labels some activists both women and men are not so accommodating in fact some claim that men cannot be regarded as feminists a view which strikes me as paradoxical since feminism strives to end sexism yet this exclusion strikes me as sexist the main rationale seems to revolve around the notion that only women can truly understand the female plight and truly know what it is like to face gender discrimination but humans are equipped with a remarkable imagination and sense of empathy if they choose to exercise it history is replete with examples of outsiders who become the iconic embodiment of certain struggles such as the privileged young doctor turned poor mans revolutionary after all you dont need to be working class to be a socialist nor a member of a minority to appreciate the suffering caused by racism people didnt need to be black to struggle against apartheid nor spanish to fight francos totalitarianism besides if the lack of direct experience disqualifies one from being a full member of the cause should we bar western feminists from showing solidarity with their sisters in less enlightened societies because they have not experienced the same magnitude of discrimination in their relatively egalitarian corner of the world moreover men do have direct experience of sexism and a major stake in combating it first of all there are the women in their lives if your wife girlfriend mother or sister experiences gender discrimination it also has an impact on you because it makes you angry and frustrated on her behalf moreover men who discriminate against women are not acting in the name of the rest of their gender and the best way to express that would be to describe ourselves as feminists in addition the macho culture which sidelines women can also belittle and ridicule the men who question it and so fighting shoulder to shoulder for the cause of gender equality is as much a progressive mans prerogative as it is a womans women be male chauvinists i believe they most certainly can some of the loudest advocates of the patriarchal order both in the past and today have been women and this highlights perfectly the fact that just because you have a vagina it does not automatically make you more sympathetic to the cause there seems to be a fear that men would try to dominate the movement elliott says that i really myself as a fullyfledged feminist i dont go to rallies nor shout slogans from the rooftops but i strive to apply the principles of equality in everything i do to my mind feminism is about gender text: in the book feminism is for everybody bell hooks defines feminism as a movement to end sexism sexist exploitation and oppression while the oxford english dictionary defines it as the advocacy of womens rights on the grounds of sexual equality youll get no argument from me on either of these interpretations theyre straightforward noncontroversial and best of all inclusive ignore all the confusing subdivisions like marxist feminism radical feminism and anarchafeminism and the arguments about whether were experiencing the thirdwave or whether were in a state of post feminism and feminism really can be summed up this concisely whats even more exciting is that if we went by either one of these definitions wed probably be hard pushed to find someone who wasnt prepared to declare themselves a feminist but is it really as straightforward as this can everyone who supports the idea of womens rights call themselves a feminist or are there other criteria that have to be met before people are allowed to sport the label like having a vagina for example or having experience of life as a female and all the attendant discriminations that that brings can men ever really be feminists or should profeminist men be consigned to the sidelines welcome allies in the struggle for gender equality but disqualified from full membership by dint of their unasked for but nonetheless privileged position as fully paid up members of the male fraternity any movement for social justice would be doing itself no favours if it deliberately excluded its own supporters from the ranks but while many feminists welcome mens championship of the cause theres still a great deal of debate over their entitlement to call themselves feminists the argument rages even amongst profeminist men with some arguing that gender should be no barrier to full and active participation and others arguing that as feminism is rooted in the womens liberation movement a movement founded by women for the advancement of women men have no right to lay claim to the tag brian klocke of the national organisation for men against sexism has argued although i believe that men can be profeminist and antisexist i do not believe we can be feminists in the strictest sense of the word in todays society men in this patriarchal system cannot remove themselves from their power and privilege in relation to women to be a feminist one must be a member of the targeted group ie a woman not only as a matter of classification but as having ones directlylived experience inform ones theory and praxis women feminists have also voiced misgivings about mens involvement in the movement some men they argue automatically assume a dominant role when they become activists claiming to be better feminists than feminist women and failing to recognise and challenge their own sexist behaviour these socalled fellow travellers merely reinforce the tired gender stereotyping that feminism seeks to subvert and by their domineering behaviour they silence womens voices and perpetuate existing male power and oppression they jockey for control and appoint themselves as spokespeople in a diverse nonhierarchical movement that neither needs nor seeks figureheads or leaders personally i have some sympathy with this position having had my own runins with socalled male feminists to be perfectly frank i really dont need men telling me how to be a better feminist or that my kind of feminism is wrong by all means debate the issues with me but define my feminism for me no i dont think so these annoying entryists aside men are welcome allies in the struggle for womens equality the current crisis in masculinity and the search for a male identity bear testimony to how centuries of patriarchal hegemony has harmed men too profeminist men have been active in challenging male behaviour and attitudes founding organisations like the white ribbon campaign which raises awareness of male violence against women and working with young men pdf in schools as both role models and mentors at the end of the day any men prepared to stand up against sexism sexual and domestic violence socially constructed gender roles and womens oppression are all right by me i dont care what they call themselves either allies fellow travellers feminist sympathisers profeminists or even just plain feminists it doesnt matter whats on the label its how feminism is translated into everyday life that matters you cant call yourself a feminist and then go home and beat your partner you cant call yourself a feminist and in the next breath deny your daughter the right to decide her own future you cant call yourself a feminist while at the same time youre patting women on the head and telling them how to think but treat us as equals and well reciprocate theres still a long way to go but well get there much faster together

housing for women have a combined annual income of just m by contrast the donkey sanctuary which has looked after donkeys received m in npc estimates the cost to society of domestic abuse sexual the government said justine jrvinen the author of the report violence against women appears regularly as the subject of media reports and in the storylines of soap operas but rarely does it come up in normal conversation which suggests there is a stigma around it the truth is it is very common every year million women experience domestic abuse at least once are sexually assaulted and raped the text: more than half of bosses consider the chances of a new recruit falling pregnant before employing them research showed today more than threequarters of employers said they would not take on a woman if they knew she was going to become pregnant within six months of starting a job and said they would feel cheated if a new recruit announced within weeks that she was expecting a child the research by the employment law advisory services elas was carried out after the firm found an increase in the number of cases it was handling involving pregnancy and new employees these included cases where candidates were asked in interview if they had plans for a family a practice banned under sex discrimination law and where job offers were withdrawn between the time of the interview and a candidate taking up a post because of pregnancy elass survey of company bosses and personnel managers found admitted that during the recruitment process they weighed up the chances of candidates getting pregnant taking into account their age and if they had recently got married almost seven in said they would like to be able to ask people about their plans to start a family during the interview process and only said they had recruited someone in the past who they knew was pregnant peter mooney head of consultancy at elas said despite legislation to outlaw discrimination companies were still shying away from recruiting pregnant women for many bosses it is down to the bottom line a pregnant member of staff will cost money however a visit to a tribunal can be even more costly he said the fact that almost eight in of those we surveyed would not employ someone if they knew they were going to fall pregnant within six months shows that discrimination is bound to happen if it is obvious a candidate is expecting a baby mooney said employers should bear in mind that the best candidate would still be the best even if they had to take time off on maternity leave he added there is always a chance that a male employee could be off because of illness so it is best to base decisions on other things rather than the threat of maternity leave since last april new mothers have been entitled to weeks of maternity leave of which are paid to qualify for leave motherstobe must tell the employer at least weeks before the baby is due during pregnancy and maternity leave it is unlawful for employers to treat employees unfairly cutting hours changing contracts or making a member of staff redundant because she is pregnant are all banned practices we are running worklife balance week text: they said having kids would change your life and they werent joking remember the days when you willingly worked all hours in the often vain hope your boss would give you something more responsible to do now with your clothes on inside out and globs of dried porridge sticking out of your hair youre just grateful they still let you in the building balancing the tattered remains of your life with that mountain of work suddenly becomes a priority you spend all your time at work thinking about when you can get home and all your time at home thinking about when you can get back to work most days feel like youre hurtling down a helterskelter only to find that instead of reaching the bottom youre right back at the top again at the office you discover a range of exciting new things to worry about if you are a mother for example youll find that beyond the statutory minimum maternity entitlement can vary wildly depending on where you work and possibly how keen your employers are to have you back fathers are generally allowed two weeks of paid paternity leave after which they may find their employer expects them to take no further part in the upbringing of their offspring then again they might love babies so much that they let you bring them in to work our sections on pay rights and discrimination will help you to negotiate these choppy waters as a parent you may feel your boss is giving you a rough deal in which case you may wish to peruse our list of exemplar employers to find out where the grass really is greener and if youre thinking of heading overseas find out what they think of working parents in other countries here if either mum or dad are staying at home to look after the children or you are sharing the load between you you will have to learn to live on one salary we have some tips on managing the financial side last but not least read how two of our readers negotiate the balancing act between work and parenting and share your tips to success

text: you and your partner are having a baby and think youve covered all the bases youve painted the spare room bought the buggy put up the cot and knitted the booties then the new kid arrives on the block and one of you typically but not always mum stays home to look after the new arrival all goes swimmingly notwithstanding the sleepless nights of course until about six months later when you visit a cashpoint and are greeted by sirens flashing red lights and a depressing clunk as the machine contemptuously spits your card back at you without any of the money you asked it for with your partners maternity pay drying up you need to get used to living on one salary and that isnt always easy when people get a pay cut which is what living on one salary effectively is they are incredibly bad at readjusting says martin lewis founder of moneysavingexpertcom people get themselves into terrible debt at this point in their lives because they spend like they used to you cannot do that so what steps can you take to soften the blow plan ahead time can fly by in the months before a baby arrives but nicholas haseman a financial adviser with prominent financial services in hounslow says you should start saving as soon as possible one of my clients knew she was going to take time off to have a baby and somehow she managed to save up an entire years salary in advance haseman says thats an extreme example but she wasnt in a particularly wellpaid job and it shows that with a bit of determination you can do it make a budget i would urge anybody to do a proper genuine budget says lewis if it shows youre spending more than you earn you need to look at what you cant do any more lewis suggests a technique he calls piggy bank budgeting to help plan for the big outlays the day your money goes into your bank account immediately siphon it off into a number of other accounts for example a bills account a holidays account a clothing account and a christmas account that way when the time comes you wont be caught out claim childcare vouchers if you have kids in childcare find out if your employer operates a childcare voucher scheme normally when you get paid for every you earn as a basic rate taxpayer youll get after tax and insurance with this scheme you can convert of your salary into vouchers to spend on childcare be tax efficient investigate whether you are eligible for working tax or child tax credits and if you are married check you are not paying tax unnecessarily on your savings transfer any joint savings or investments into your spouses name while he or she is not working as they will usually be liable to pay less income tax than you says haseman you could also consider registering the nonworking partner as a non taxpayer cut your spending from taking your own sandwiches to work to shopping for bargains on ebay and picking up free stuff on freecycle there are all sorts of ways you can work to reduce your living costs for virtually effortfree packed lunches cook an extra portion of your evening meal the night before and bring it in cold the following day and if youre feeling more ambitious check out the tasty homemade lunch recipes in canteen culture in office hours on mondays so our experts agree with a little bit of forward planning and attention to finance living off one income neednt be a headache

text: mike and albertine davies with their children alex aged one and linus three mike and albertine davies both work part time so they can share responsibility for looking after their sons linus and alex here they outline the pros and cons of their choice its the beginning of the summer term and next years school timetables will soon start to take shape for us that means lots of head scratching about how we can make shared childcare work for another year as a teacher and a probation officer we are incredibly lucky in that the teachers hours are fairly family friendly and probation hours can be pretty much worked around them we also have an obliging grandmother to our boys for the last couple of years she has provided one days childcare a fortnight which makes the whole thing viable although the dual parttime routine had been the great childcare plan for as long as we can remember we had no faith that things were going to work until suddenly it was all arranged to complicate things the school runs a fortnightly timetable which leads to some funny hours for both of us but it seems to work another downside is money although if you are considering giving up work altogether and living on one salary our way is a slightly better financial option two halfsalaries add up to slightly more than one whole one once you add in taxation career progression or lack of is also a problem parttime status should not by law be a barrier to advancement that would be discrimination but there are some jobs where it is not viable to be part time more legitimately it takes you twice as long to notch up the necessary experience for promotion we may also be imagining things but it seems harder for a parttime man to be taken seriously in his career than a woman people are used to women looking after babies but are often surprised if a man wants to do it thats the bad news and it is outweighed by the good spending half our time with the children helps to keep job stress in perspective and just as were beginning to get weary of the highcriticism lowthanks atmosphere of home we get to go back to work where people ask for things nicely and no one weeps if you cut their toast into the wrong shape the boys are lovely but work can seem easy by comparison the other really big upside of sharing childcare is that the other person knows really really knows exactly what its like we both know how tiring it is and how joyful it can be we both have good bonds with the children since we spend a lot of time with them and it has also had a positive effect on our own relationship since it feels very equal to be dividing both types of work between us last and best is the reduction of guilt associated with going back to work and actually enjoying having a career and some time for yourself when were at work we dont worry about what the children are doing and we dont feel bad for not being there since one of us is always around sharing childcare seems to offer pretty big emotional benefits both for them and us

text: the true cost of violence as more than three million women in the united kingdom discover each year is far too high these women are the victims behind the headline stories of rape domestic violence trafficking and forced marriage that our media reports almost every day their physical injuries range from bruises black eyes and broken bones to permanent disability and occasionally death remember the case of banaz mahmod who was killed by her family for falling in love with the wrong man other physical manifestations of violence like sexually transmitted diseases and unwanted pregnancies take longer to appear but they can deepen the other less immediately visible consequence of violence psychological damage but let us be clear the effects of this violence is not confined to its three million annual victims one way or another it touches us all we may have been attacked ourselves we may know people in violent relationships we may have friends who have been raped or stalked we may have seen the effect that an attack has had on those close to a victim and almost all women will have experienced the fear of sexual violence which plays such a large part in the in womens fear of crime but the cost of violence is not confined to the physical and psychological trauma of it its victims and their families violence costs taxpayers billions of pounds a year in health care policing and criminal justice and rape crisis centres refuges social workers and health workers have to mop up its aftermath on a daily basis for these and many other reasons tackling violence against women is one of the governments key priorities and i am proud what we have done over the past decade to address this scourge like the introduction of specialist domestic violence courts the rolling out of sexual assault referral centres the establishment of a united kingdom human trafficking centre and increased funding for rape crisis centres we have published a new report tackling violence against women a crossgovernment narrative which shows how government the police local authorities and other agencies are working more closely than ever to tackle domestic violence sexual offences and human trafficking the narrative shows that the number of convictions and successful prosecutions have risen significantly in recent years the number of rape convictions is higher today than in the reporting of rape is more than double today what it was in thanks to improvements in the criminal justice system and support systems which have made victims increasingly confident about coming forward successful prosecutions for domestic violence have increased by half from in to by december some m has been provided by government in the last four years to support victims of sexual violence in addition the new equality duties we have placed on the public sector put this country ahead of most of the world in the area of protection against discrimination the gender equality duty requires public bodies to promote equality between women and men this is a powerful tool in efforts to make sure that local authorities health and police services address issues like violence against women that perpetuate inequality the newly established equality and human rights commission has made it clear that gender equality is a priority for it too but much more needs to be done and the ministers for women are determined to lead a crossgovernment strategy to deal with the root causes of this violence we support the end violence against women coalitions efforts to raise awareness of this scourge by publishing an analysis of how each government department is tackling it i am delighted that the crown prosecution service has for the second year running had the highest score of all departments its violence against women strategy which makes the connections between specific forms of violence is a beacon in whitehall violence against women is an international as well as a national problem and we welcome the recently launched united nations campaign to tackle violence their secretary general ban kimoon says that it is for the women and girls who have the right to live free of violence today and in the future the government wants the united kingdom to be at the forefront of global action to tackle violence against women and we are committed to developing a more strategic approach that allows us to end it meanwhile in the uk rape crisis centres domestic violence refuges and support organisations for women fleeing from violence are quite literally lifesavers they help women to get the safety they need they support them through the justice system and enable them to move on with their lives they also play a critical role in raising awareness about violence against women providing expertise to the government and driving this agenda forward we will continue to work with these organisations and across government to free women from the scourge of violence that is costing them and our country so dear

text: baby briefcase is this really a good idea photo gettymarc carter trying to fire off emails while a toddler spews curdled milk across your keyboard is clearly not an ideal scenario for most workers so can it ever be a good idea to bring your babies into work absolutely yes according to the parenting in the workplace institute a usbased group which claims wheeling your tots into the office is a viable inexpensive tool for helping employees return to work sooner lowering turnover improving morale increasing overall productivity enhancing teamwork and collaboration recruiting new employees attracting new customers and making existing customers more loyal phew in todays g we asked three of our journalists with babies to put this theory to the test you can read about their increasingly futile attempts to get any work done here despite this many people feel that companies could do more to accommodate new parents and mothers in particular in their workforces and more firms are offering subsidised crche facilities either on site or in local nurseries as the benefits of retaining skilled workers are realised equally though there are plenty of workers without kids who resent being told when they can and cant book their holidays and are tired of picking up the slack for those colleagues who are parents are our workplaces becoming too childfriendly or are we making vital progress in better accommodating working parents later this month both on the money blog and in the pages of work and office hours well be bringing you a week of themed blogs features and ideas relating to worklife balance so let us know what you think

text: i may not have read all the major papers cover to cover over the past weekend but if my attempt at a fairly broad sweep is acceptable i saw only one mention of a revolutionary move in a political party as reported in the herald following a decision at its annual conference the scottish socialist party is to have joint male and female leaders its the second time scotland has explored this route the scottish green party also have male and female coconvenors unfortunately no space was given to the thinking behind this move or its implications for elections and candidacy but revolutionary nevertheless it was and is in one bold move this party has swept aside all the arguments about gender neutrality and meritocracy and replaced them with an acceptance maybe promotion even of gender difference it says men and women are different so a polity must be represented by one of each the fact that the ssp is much depleted post tommy sheridan and that it has a very live history of gender battles of its own should not reduce our interest in the move nor should the limited nature of the move only the party leaders are affected so far diminish the impact of the development if nothing else it presents an opportunity for observers to speculate on the effect such a policy might have on the behaviour and treatment of women in politics and the impact on the broadly acknowledged male often macho culture of our parliaments if eventually there were just as many women around as men jackie ashleys recent column decrying the apparent dearth of feisty swaggering women actually complained that women had become too soft if that is so it is only a recent phenomenon in a political field that is always described in masculine warring terms women have had to put on their armour and imitate the behaviour of soldiers those that have made it to the very top condi rice thatcher golda meir have always prided themselves on their ability to be men in the face of difficulties but if we are to change the dominant culture and its outcomes in any significant way is it not necessary for alternative cultures to be fostered once women have equality still very patchy even in this part of the world though it is the question of difference becomes less charged and more promising is there something specific that women can bring to politics that will begin to reshape the political culture not just its policies if there are enough of them while it is often pointed out that women champion family and children in the policy sphere what do they bring that is new to the way politicians behave in the house of commons for example or to how the government reacts and responds to conflict to date despite david milibands championing of the phrase i have never heard a female politician talk about soft power is it because of the fear of appearing too feminine and by implication too weak when in competition with men for a chance to represent a constituency that may be necessary but when women have a truly equal opportunity to serve it may change dramatically until now women have not emphasised the feminine aspect of their thinking in order to appear gender neutral it may be easier however controversial to identify feminine thinking as something that both men and women are capable of but may represent more women than men for example it is more feminine to respond to conflict with empathy than with a system of control specific feminine abilities include using intuition and emotional intelligence making relationships networking mediating all what you might call soft capacities both in business and in conflict these are increasingly recognised as the strongest qualities not the weakest would more women in public life lead to a less ambiguous appreciation of soft power but it would be no easy task to create the physical mental or most crucially the media space to allow a new feminine culture to emerge and flourish not as feisty competition to masculine culture but as a viable partner to it within the pressures of political life too often women themselves censor words like compassion kindness and love and can betray each other in the race to be a better man than their colleagues just as often they simply dont turn out for each other as if they dont believe in their own vision for change how is it for example that so many women find themselves trapped in the fight to be allowed to work often for a pittance at the expense of being able to take care of their children why do so many women accept that the ideal of having both a family and a career can only be pursued by juggling and a selfish greed for having it all why is the feminine call for a more rounded life both for women and men not regarded as completely acceptable to politicians and the media so much so that they would fund it such a change in culture is still far off but it could come into view if there was a huge influx of women into public life in the past year i have begun to visit a number of womens groups not political feminists pursuing rights but women exploring the feminine spirit regular attendees range from psychologists to company directors only some are mothers after a lifetime of denying their differences with men they have begun to dig them out and prize them our conversations cover anything from consciousness to poverty war to spirituality most challenging is the ideal of not setting goals and agendas but just prizing our ability to be together as women and seeing what emerges outside of the usual frameworks and priorities in stark contrast to so many other meetings and salons that i attend these meetings are passionate joyful and hopeful what might be the effect of this kind of input consistently expressed in policy making allowing women to take an equal share of responsibility in public life may sound logical but it is still revolutionary and a long way off but thanks to the scottish greens and socialists it is not a mere fantasy

text: truth is often said to be the first casualty in wartime but if the real truth is told it is women who are the first casualties in conflict zones the united nations childrens agency unicef recently observed sexual violence usually spreads like an epidemic whether it is civil war pogroms or other armed conflicts all too often womens bodies become part of the battlefield the victims of largescale sexual atrocities range from baby girls to old women in darfur janjaweed militia kidnapped a yearold girl and gangraped her for a week pulling her legs so far apart that she was crippled for life the biggest fear of rape victims in darfur however is that they will never find a husband under sharia law raped women are prosecuted for adultery or fornication last year at least two young women in sudan were sentenced to death by stoning as refugees international observes the government is more likely to take action against those who report and document rape than those who commit it in the wars now savaging the democratic republic of congo rape victims also take most of the blame after being raped congolese women are banished by their husbands and ostracised by their communities often they are genitally mutilated by a gunshot or tossed on a fire naked in cultures where girls and women are married off and chastity is central to womanhood all is lost for a woman who loses her honour the subsequent stigma often is a heavier burden than the assault itself so it should be no surprise that most of these wounded girls and women keep silent during the balkan wars of the s women were raped for the purpose of bearing the enemys children according to european union estimates women in bosnia alone were victims of rape the women have been largely left to themselves traumatised by their experiences and condemned to a life of poverty in an estimated two million women were victims of the red armys sexual cruelties not only german women but also jewish women in hiding concentration camp survivors and resistance fighters according to the german journalist ruth andreasfriedrich the shame felt about lost honour created an atmosphere of suicide in april there were more than suicides in berlin husbands fathers and teachers pressured women and girls to end their own lives after russian soldiers raped them because their honour was their major concern for many girls and women nonmarital sex remains worse than death so it is all the more striking and painful that for so long this specific war crime has received little attention during the second world war the prohibition on rape by soldiers was well established in international law but the postwar nuremberg and tokyo war crimes tribunals prosecuted only a handful of cases during the genocide in rwanda mass rape was the rule but sexual assault was included only accidentally and secondarily in the rwanda tribunals indictments after a rwandan woman spontaneously declared before the tribunal that she and other women had been raped before the massacre a female judge followed up and revealed the enormous scale of sexual violence against women the rwanda tribunal was the first in history to describe rape as a possible act of genocide in the international criminal tribunal for former yugoslavia in the hague condemned the systematic rape of women as a crime against humanity in the landmark foca case the icty convicted three bosnian serbs of rape torture and enslavement of muslim women in girls some of them just years old were gangraped for weeks yet the perpetrators of wartime mass rape and other forms of sexual violence usually are not prosecuted recently the congolese militia leader thomas lubanga became the first prisoner to be tried at the international criminal court in the hague for the recruitment of child soldiers yet the indictments failure to mention violence against women is a huge shock to the victims according to congolese human rights organisations in a petition they asked the icc to investigate mass rapes committed by all parties in the conflict the impunity that is characteristic of these heinous crimes must stop rape and other forms of sexual violence against women should be openly discussed by governments members of parliament militia leaders and opinion leaders prosecution must become the rule the icc and other tribunals must give a clear signal to the perpetrators for women who have been victims of rape there are no monetary benefits memorials or mourning rituals that must change as well there should be a monument to the unknown raped woman at the icc maybe then its judges would pay closer attention to sexual violence against women in association with project syndicate

text: tina downham a former headhunter has been a fulltime mum to holli and daisy four for the past six years and she loves it to be in a situation where you can enjoy your children and not pay somebody else to look after them is great she says looking after children is the biggest job you will ever have if you put them in nursery you get the worst of them at the beginning and the end of the day how do you ever do any bonding but downham has seen things from both sides in her old company she managed a team of people working fulltime while holli was in nursery as a toddler she was so stressed and harried that she remembers trailing an ambulance through rush hour traffic to get to work on time one day she picked her daughter up from nursery at the pm cutoff time and holli then three said mummy do i have to be the last one here she realised it was time to quit it makes me feel sick when i think about what i had to juggle she and husband clive a power tools executive downsized to one salary and moved from buckinghamshire to taunton she blames materialism for the fact that few women want to do what she has done i dont know why there arent a few more mums going without a few things because what you get back is so much more but downhams views are increasingly rare and she is one of a dying breed around seven out of eight mothers now work according to a report published last week by yougov the number of stayathome mothers has dropped by a quarter in the past years in there were million fulltime mothers in the uk the new research estimates that the figure will fall below million by the survey concluded that most parents cannot afford for one of them not to work couples think they need an income of before they can afford for the mother to stay at home and the average male income in the uk is this is proof that a stayathome parent is a logistical impossibility for most households these conclusions are fascinating if slightly questionable as anyone who lives in an affluent middleclass suburb of london will tell you in some areas there is no shortage of fulltime mothers if anything their numbers appear to have increased in recent years part of the yougov research is based on a survey of only people and almost all of it is heavily weighted how do you define stayathome mother what if youre on maternity leave or a shortterm career break the overall picture nationwide however is undeniable there are now fewer stayathome mothers than ever and the credit crunch is only likely to send more mothers back to work interestonly mortgages and fixedterm rates coming to an end are a powerful motivation to return i know of several fulltime mothers who have started job searches in recent weeks this is what is sad for the current generation of mothers says mary aston who left her job in a bank in to be a fulltime mother to to william now libby and kathy in bruton somerset her husband mark is a crops specialist she did not work again for years i feel very sorry for parents nowadays who both feel they have to go out to work she says mothers miss out on a lot if theyre not with their children between nought and five i was lucky that i didnt have to work we didnt have any money i remember having a week for everything but we didnt mind i felt bringing up the children was the best rolei could have nowadays parents feel guilty about not going to work in those days i would have felt guilty if i did go to work until as recently as the s it was assumed that to be anything other than a fulltime mother was damaging to children but the nonworking mother is a purely thcentury construct women have always worked whether they were paid for it or not in what my fouryearold son calls the olden days children were brought up not by one woman but by an extended family it is only in recent history that we have started to worry about things such as whether your parents mess you up by working or not working the stayathome mother was born in the s and s as domestic service died says professor pat thane of the institute of historical research by the end of the second world war mothers had to look after their own children because they couldnt find other women to do it she says this coincided with the growth of a middle class who could afford for a woman to stay at home crucially at the same time news of an exciting new science psychology was reaching a mass audience lots of women listened to childcare experts influenced by modern psychology whose work was available in cheap paperbacks in the s this new thinking most of it under the banner of attachment theory put a new onus on the mother and the mother alone to form an exclusive bond with her child women in this postwar period already suffered from exactly the same double bind that mothers have today in the s many women of childbearing age found themselves welleducated and newly equipped with work skills but they were also living in a culture where it was considered best to stay at home with your children surely it had to be if psychological experts said so this view has persisted to this day many mothers cite financial necessity as the reason they work implying that if they did not need the money they would do the right thing and stay at home at least though we now have the choice in the first wave of feminism many women began to question their roles as wives and mothers some virtually walking out on their families the daughter of the feminist author alice walker has recently spoken of her mother officially resigning from her maternal role in provincial britain however this radicalism passed a lot of women by in the early s joy gower from norwich gave up the job she loved as manager of a hair salon to stay at home for years with her sons gareth and lee now and respectively my husband did not approve of his wife going out to work he thought that if you had children it was your duty to stay at home i did enjoy bringing my sons up but i also wanted to be me i was glad that i could be there for all the sports days but i do look back now and see that i was oppressed there is some sadness and regret i was capable of a lot more despite feminism she says it was everyones expectation in the s that a woman should stay at home i didnt know any women who were working at that time unless they were childminding or starting up a nursery i did as many things as i possibly could to keep my mind occupied including an open university course but a lot of us had husbands who would say well if you are going to work you still have to do all the housework anyway it was easier she says to take the housekeeping money and keep quiet eventually she trained as a manager for avon and later as a hypnotherapist once her boys grew up she divorced and later remarried choice though has brought a pressure to bear on todays stayathome mothers they are made to feel they should justify their existence as erika sales fulltime mother to oscar two and francis four in twickenham southwest london explains you do get this feeling sometimes that youre not good enough any more in that workplace sense that maybe people think youre not as intelligent any more you remind yourself that isnt true but it does knock your confidence there are times when i think i should look for a job but then i have to remind myself that its not what i want to do she left a career in marketing to stay at home her husband adrian is an accountant luckily she says she has a lot of friends who are in the same position a lot of the mums at the school gate are stayathome those who do work work parttime or from home so no i dont feel unusual several of my friends are the same age and in the same situation we feel that weve had our careers and we dont have to go back like many older mothers after two decades of work she feels that she has achieved everything she wanted and now this is her family time i do think i would have a different relationship with the children if i was working i would probably feel that i would have to spoil them more to make up for not being there i just like them knowing i am there for them all the time sales also wanted to replicate the experience she had with her own stayathome mother over the years this has been a common motivation faith quance from sheffield married at in and had a daughter and two sons over the next six years trained as a medical secretary she did not go back to work for years i just wanted to be at home with them and do the things my own mother had done for me she says there were times later when i regretted it on a personal level but not from the familys point of view i didnt resent being at home with my children i enjoyed it although we could have done with more money having watched her children bring up her four grandchildren however she sees now that things can be done differently and she has reevaluated her views on nursery some of my anxieties to do with not being the principle carer have been rebutted by seeing how well nursery children do they gain all sorts of social skills that the child who was at home with mum doesnt seem to have one of my grandchildren was in childcare from six months and he is a very extrovert sociable child and has gained a lot from it i dont condemn people who send their children to nursery but i didnt want it years ago i dont know if i would be different now she does not envy her daughters generation the cost of everything is so enormous and peoples expectations are unrealistic they want to have these beautiful homes and it just isnt possible to do that and have contented children if the financial situation is complex for a lot of families at the moment there is at least one positive development says jill harris mother of tom and olivia seven from warlingham surrey flexible working last year she went back to work after six years at home i didnt intend to become a stayathome mother and certainly not for that long i just didnt believe that there were genuine parttime flexible jobs out there things have changed considerably in the past five years a former communications executive she now works as a schools manager with women like us a london recruitment firm that links up companies looking for highly qualified candidates for parttime positions they explicitly recruit fulltime mums who have dropped out of the job market the rise in flexibility has to be one of the main factors in the decline of fulltime motherhood but the real nail in the coffin has been the housing market i feel quite strongly that this generation was fed a bit of a lie says francesca todd the practicalities of bringing up children and running a house have not changed if anything it has got harder because the price of property has gone through the roof the mother of jemima four and william one she and her musician husband nick moved from southeast london to welwyn garden city herts and downsized so that she could give up her office job in the civil service but they still need two salaries she works from home two days a week fulltime motherhood was not an option she says because she enjoys her work too much and if childcare were less expensive she would work more the yougov survey also found that the cost of childcare has risen by in the past six years and will rise another by what im doing now is the right thing for the children but it has been really hard and at times extremely lonely and dull todd says but when i was both working in an office and looking after the children it was the hardest time of my life i would have to put on this professional mask in the morning and pretend to be cheerful at work when i had been up all night with the children at least if youre a fulltime mother you can hide away be grumpy and not have to pretend that youre having it all and doing it all pippa menzies also embodies this new kind of working stayathome motherhood she and her husband rory do not have any childcare for jake three jamie months and archie five months they look after the children themselves but they also run riverdale house a bampb in alfriston east sussex she left her career running an mps office to spend more time with the children politics and family life do not mix its impossible its a hour job she says then theres the money element as soon as you have two children its not financially worthwhile and work becomes a luxury now the children have fulltime parents but were working as well one thing has been completely lost she says we have got a lot more family time together but there is no time for yourself at all because it is relentless its either the kids or the business or both you have to make a sacrifice though no matter what you do sometimes its money sometimes its career sometimes its the children she has days when she doubts herself yesterday jamie poured a pot of hot tea over himself and i found myself thinking if i was a proper fulltime mum would he have done that but thats the state of modern motherhood i think you feel guilty whatever you do at least to her children she says she has the appearance of being a traditional mother while for herself she still maintains an income and a career perhaps rather than disappearing the stayathome mother has reappeared in a more creative entrepreneurial form even tina downham in taunton a staunch supporter of fulltime motherhood is starting a second career as an artist she has just sold her first painting for meanwhile though mothers now face numerous pressures and difficult decisions there will always be a small army of stayathome mothers who love what they do and dont want to change it for the world and to hell with social trends as long as you can afford it as sales puts it the thing is i do absolutely adore being at home with my children thats what gets you through when youre thinking that maybe you should go back to work or that youre not good enough you are there for every moment when they do every little thing for the first time and i just love that that is the reason you do it this article was amended on wednesday may we inadvertently changed the gender of professor pat thane of the institute of historical research from female to male during the editing of the article above apologies this has been corrected

text: most new fathers like to spend some time at home when their babies are born the introduction of two weeks of paid paternity leave was intended to make this easier but the new rules are not all they were cracked up to be not everyone qualifies for paternity pay and even when they do the benefit is so low that many fathers dont bother to claim paternity leave for employees was introduced five years ago it allows fathers or the partner of a woman having a child including samesex partners to take up to two weeks of paid leave after their baby is born within days after the birth during their leave fathers receive statutory paternity pay which is or per cent of their average weekly earnings if this figure is lower employers can reclaim all or nearly all of the leave from their national insurance contributions claiming paid paternity leave however is not always straightforward as alastair macdonald from armadale in scotland discovered last year macdonald was disappointed to find that he was not eligible for paid paternity leave on the arrival of his third child because he had changed his job within weeks of the expected date of birth even though the job change was not voluntary because he had been made redundant he says that his new employers are only a small firm so they couldnt afford to pay me if they werent able to reclaim the money from the government they offered me unpaid leave instead but i couldnt afford to take time off without my wages he believes it would be fairer if eligibility was based on his national insurance contribution record pointing out that he has been paying contributions continuously since he started work at most men dont have a problem claiming paternity pay says kathy rogan rights adviser at working families the worklife balance campaign organisation but difficulties can arise she warns sometimes employers will refuse because an employee hasnt given them the full weeks written notice required in another case a man was threatened with losing a substantial part of his bonus if he took the time off but we told him his employer could not do this as in law you cannot be subjected to a detriment if you assert a right sometimes small employers will say they havent heard of paternity pay but in this situation the easiest way for an employee to enforce his right is to complain direct to the revenue as they are responsible for administering paternity pay we also get queries from selfemployed men but unfortunately they dont qualify anyway even when fathers are eligible for paternity pay they do not always claim it adrienne burgess research manager at the fatherhood institute says paternity pay is so low that many men cant afford to take paternity leave although around per cent of men take time off around the time of their babys birth many use their ordinary holiday entitlement instead the general feeling is that professional men tend to take paternity leave because they work for the type of companies that will top up the benefit so they get their full salary but they are in the minority the majority of men in lowerpaid jobs are unlikely to get a topup from their employer so they will use their holiday entitlement in order to remain on full pay but this is terrible for families because it means dads ordinary holiday is squeezed the charity working families would like to see paternity pay increased jonathan swan its policy and research officer says we would like it brought into line with the first six weeks of statutory maternity pay when mothers receive per cent of their usual weekly earnings this would give fathers a proper incentive to take paternity leave we would also like it to be extended and made more flexible so it does not have to be taken in one block there are also criticisms of the governments plans for additional paternity leave which it has pledged to introduce before the end of the current parliament this would give employed fathers a right to take an additional weeks off work with pay to care for their child in its first year in place of the mother if she has returned to work and not used all her paid maternity leave adrienne burgess of the fatherhood institute says one of the problems with these plans is that fathers wont be able to take the leave unless their partner is entitled to maternity leave so if the woman is not working or is selfemployed then fathers wont get it also because the government wants to encourage breastfeeding fathers wont be able to take the leave in the first six months of the babys life we see this as social engineering on the part of the government they should grant parental leave and let couples choose how they take it they also need to pay fathers per cent or per cent of their salary during their leave otherwise very few will take it up fortunately for alastair macdonald who wasnt eligible for paid paternity leave his wife mhari had their daughter ceilidh on christmas eve so he had a few days of paid holiday straight after the birth anyway tax help for families on the plus side there are child benefit and child tax credits that can help to boost the familys income child benefit is given automatically and is currently per week for the first child and for other children child tax credits depend on income but according to the government nine out of families qualify most get at least the basic family element worth for the current tax year if their income is no more than a year up to if you have a child under one for lower earners a child element is also available which is worth up to and is payable for each child working tax credits may also be available depending on income and the number of children in the family according to hmrc figures a couple with an income of with two children could qualify for combined child and working tax credits of a year or a week families who are eligible for working tax credit can additionally receive help with per cent of eligible childcare costs up to a maximum of per week for one child or for two or more children eligibility inquiries can be made through a confidential tax credits helpline parents also receive a child trust fund of to invest taxfree on behalf of their new arrival they can add a further per year to the account but there will also be plenty of expenses associated with a new arrival in particular parents should remember to take out extra life insurance says graeme mitchell of independent financial advisers lowland financial to protect their dependents against financial hardship in case of their early death term assurance is the cheapest option

text: since the beginning of the year the boards of norwegian public limited companies have had to be female if they dont comply the state will shut them down sound like a crazy idea well it has worked norwegian company boards now have the highest number of female directors anywhere in the world perhaps britain should consider introducing a similar initiative the law was the brainchild of an unlikely feminist icon former businessman ansgar gabrielsen was a conservative trade and industry minister when he announced the law in i could not see why after years of having an equal ratio of women and men in universities and having so many educated women with experience there were so few of them on boards he told me the law was not about getting equality between the sexes it was about the fact that diversity is a value in itself that it creates wealth from my time in the business world i saw how board members were picked they come from the same small circle of people they go hunting and fishing together they are buddies today many directors ive spoken to say boards have become more competent board recruiters have been forced to look beyond their immediate circles of friends and colleagues the pool of candidates has widened so you have more chances of getting good directors and since you have people with more diverse backgrounds you have a multiplicity of opinions and approaches at board meetings which leads to better decisionmaking the law has focused peoples minds on diversity instead of endless talkingshops about breaking the glass ceiling people have had to think practically about how to have more women in top executive positions it has given rise to other initiatives too the confederation of norwegian enterprise nho which had started a programme called female future to put female board candidates in touch with company owners has now launched another initiative called ethnic future the aim is to promote more men and women from ethnic minorities to executive positions many women who took part in female future were also offered top management positions not just directorships company owners saw their cv in the programmes database thought they would be good for their companies and offered them jobs in the uk only of directors of ftse firms were female in how long do we have to wait until the generations of experienced women that have been working in business for decades get to these positions the debate often focuses on what women should do more to get the seats they should get more experience they should spend more time at work they should cultivate more networks aside from the fact that that women are already doing that this argument is focusing on the wrong group of people the debate should be about board recruiters why do they pick only men change doesnt happen naturally it always needs to be provoked with bold initiatives they are always decried at the beginning and then they are taken for granted gabrielsen did exactly that he announced the quota law without consulting his party leader or the prime minister his party the conservatives at first protested but then fell into line the leftwing parties had not other choice but to follow suit meanwhile the business community which at first was up in arms eventually took the pragmatic approach and complied with the law none of the directors i spoke to thought quotas are a good idea per se however they thought they were necessary to bring about change perhaps its time britain does the same

text: eighty years ago this week women won the right to vote on the same terms as men the culmination of a battle that depending on where you think it first began had already lasted at least a century like so many longanticipated revolutions it ended a deep injustice without having quite the transformative effect on political priorities that some had hoped it turns out that equality a universally recognised indicator of the health of a society does not just happen it has to be fought for and each gain has to be protected that is why harriet harmans equality bill although its ambition goes well beyond gender equality is necessary it also explains the outraged howls that met the proposals when they were unveiled last week selfevidently britain is not an equal society women now do better at school and university than men but still earn less at work some ethnicminority britons experience persistent health inequalities disabled people routinely struggle to enjoy the same opportunities as their peers and pensioners individual medical and care needs often seem invisible to the professionals they encounter the new bill is an important signal that the government is prepared to do something about it although not as much as the campaigners would like the most contentious of the proposals is to allow employers to discriminate in order to achieve diversity this has been widely assumed to mean that men will suffer unjustly but there will be occasions when in the interests of diversity a man is the best choice in theory that is as illegal at the moment as not hiring a woman because she is of childbearing age this is the boldest of proposals that elsewhere show signs of having been diluted by a nervous government on the intractable pay gap ms harman believes greater transparency will have an important cultural impact certainly if women have evidence that men are paid more for work of equal value they can start to ask questions but that is only the start whitehall pay audits introduced five years ago have apparently done nothing to deter the treasury from paying men on average more than women more work is needed to explain whether this is pay policy or job segregation meanwhile even where equal pay cases have been successful tribunals cannot impose equality on an employer unless the employee is still there some local authorities losers in several longdrawn out equal value cases say they cannot afford to pay their women employees what they are owed the bill has no answers while its timescale is vague and its enforcement processes are so far illdefined and likely to affect only larger employers so not the end of the battle just one more skirmish
