text: when i was and looking for my first proper job i successfully sat the aptitude test for the post office then a few weeks afterwards i was called in for an interview i was told that id done really well in the exam and that i was one of only two candidates shortlisted for the vacancy it was between me and a bloke of the same age so far so good everything went well until about midway through my grilling when one of the managers asked youre not planning to do anything silly like get married and have babies are you if i remember rightly this was the point at which my jaw momentarily hit the floor fully aware that this was a totally inappropriate question in fact unlawful and blatantly discriminatory even back then in but desperate for the job and not wanting to make a bad impression by appearing confrontational i mumbled something vague like no of course not not for a few years anyway and hoped that that would be enough to persuade him no surprises there of my suitability for a career in such a prestigious institution suffice to say i didnt get the job sir alan sugar recently argued that not being able to find out about a persons intentions to have children or not creates an air of uncertainty it puts doubts in the mind of a prospective employer about the commitment and suitability of the candidate for the job the reality is that some employers are hesitant to employ women in key roles regretfully theres concern in the back of their minds that women may not be a good choice because they may come with complications and have their work and career disrupted by family stuff he went on to suggest that the employment laws disallowing a prospective employer from asking a woman questions about her childcare arrangements should be scrapped and that instead women should be encouraged to explain to their interviewers just how organised they are when it comes to sorting out who looks after the kids thus alleviating any worries that family stuff might get in the way of their work performance sugars comments which openly acknowledged and further encouraged the discrimination women are subjected to in the jobs market met with barely a whimper from the mainstream media a striking contrast to the reception given on thursday to harriet harmans announcement of the new equality bill the difference harmans proposals are aimed at alleviating the endemic and structural inequalities faced by both women and ethnic minorities in the workplace let the backlash commence white men face jobs ban as new favours ethnic minorities and women screamed the front page of the daily express while the mail talked about the controversial new equality bill that could discriminate against white men well im sorry if this sounds harsh but quite frankly i really couldnt care less if privileged white men are about to get a taste of their own medicine but theyre not anyway so i dont understand what all the fuss is about as yvonne roberts pointed out yesterday under the new law employers can give preferential treatment to women and ethnic minorities if equally qualified without the risk of being sued note that phrase if equally qualified theres no suggestion that women or minority ethnic candidates should be allowed to jump ahead of betterqualified white male candidates and no suggestion that members of underrepresented groups with fewer qualifications should be privileged over other candidates simply because they identify as members of those groups this is positive action not positive discrimination and as harman sayspdf the new legislation will simply give more scope for employers if they want to increase the number of women or black or asian employees under these proposals public sector employers wont be forced to employ more women but if the employer feels that their workforce isnt reflective of the diversity of the community they serve this new bill will enable them to change all that while at the same time removing any fear of a legal challenge from unsuccessful candidates theres nothing controversial about this it simply reinforces what some decent employers have been trying to achieve for years but it gives them the added protection of a legal defence if theyre ever called upon to justify their decision strangely enough theres rarely a comparable outcry when it comes to the outrageous differential between the hourly pay rates of fulltime men compared to parttime women workers when women are systematically discriminated against paid less sacked or refused employment because theyre pregnant or theres a possibility they might get pregnant at some vague and faroff date sexually harassed continually overlooked for promotion thanks to glass ceilings and sticky floors and excluded from opportunities to meet with those who might help advance their careers when they place family responsibilities ahead of a game of golf and because theyre not wearing the old school tie everyone just shrugs their shoulders and says yeah well lifes not fair get over it and yet at the first sign that men might be losing some of their privilege suddenly lifes not fair becomes and were not going to stand for it hypocritical you bet surprising unfortunately no well after decades of employment legislation that still hasnt managed to achieve equality for women at work its about bloody time something was done so well done harriett for this one and keep up the good work

text: harriet harman is under fire again for proposing that employers should be allowed to discriminate in order to ensure diversity this has got a great storm going in those parts of the media that are fuelled by stories about politicalcorrectnessgonemad positive discrimination is in the eye of the beholder which is why it has been used since time immemorial to ensure that white middle class men get all the best jobs harman wants to use it to help employers make sure their companies reflect the world around them which means she says that when faced with two or more candidates of otherwise equal merit the employer can select the one that most fits their diversity requirements that might be the black candidate or the female candidate and if the job was for a primary school teacher it would probably be the male candidate for some warped reason it is considered acceptable to discuss the shortage of male role models in junior schools but pc madness to propose a solution to the lack of women role models at company board level it seems likely that some employers certainly larger ones and those like the bbc that operate very publicly discreetly discriminate already it would be very hard to prove that they didnt although the persistence in some sectors of the mainlywhite work force suggests that they must and consider the inequity of the allwomen workplace where low pay is the norm and the extraordinary difficulty of proving that the womens work is of equal value to mens care assistants versus gardeners for example in many local authorities more diversity in the workplace finally taken at last the government is acting to remove one excuse for the lack of women and black and ethnic minorities in good jobs it is not going to work magic but it is one more brick in the wall to which harman in her unpopular and bloodyminded way must now have added a whole row

text: harriet harman seems rather confused with her plans about the gender pay gap we have structural discrimination on pay indeed we do and rightly so there is a gender pay gap and what we should be interested in are the reasons that gap exists and persists our reaction might be different if we find that the gap is caused by rampant sexism by capitalist pigdogs directly discriminating against women than it would be if there were some innate differences between men and women that made them pursue different goals that direct discrimination does indeed exist although thankfully at much lower levels than in previous decades the women at work commission report told us that direct discrimination accounts for of the gender pay gap in the financial services industry the rest is indeed caused by other factors theres a multiplicity of these other factors as well maternity leave means substantial time out of the workforce leading to other things being equal lower human capital the desire to spend time raising said children rather than chasing promotion leads among those who so decide to lower wages women take more sick leave than men and yes at least some of it is due to the biological difference between the sexes the reproductive differences there are many more of such findings and yes when totted up they do explain the rest of that gender pay gap all of these latter differences lead to what an economist would refer to as rational discrimination as opposed to that earlier irrational or taste discrimination for the money that an employer is paying out women do less work or as in fact these things pan out those who are less productive at work receive less pay yes its structural discrimination too but its discrimination of a type that we actually desire those whose work is more valuable to an employer get paid more this is the very basis of a market system and it is impossible for one to operate without such discrimination harman also said parttime women receive less pay than fulltime men do you think that thats because they are less intelligent less committed less hardworking less qualified its not the case women less intelligent than men no no one is still spouting that lie are parttime workers less committed than full time yes by a certain measurable number of hours a week actually theyve decided not to commit to fulltime work in favour of things more important to them in this life similarly with the hardworking part we can measure the number of hours that they are working less hard yes parttime workers do tend to be less qualified in the way that employers value qualification the women at work commission makes a useful observation about why all parttime workers both men and women make less per hour than their fulltime brothers and sisters because it costs more to hire parttimers youve got to pay for two sets of training two sets of management two sets of perks and yes parttime workers are less productive per hour as well im all for continuing to wipe out direct or taste discrimination on the basis of haplotype but im not in favour of this attempt to wipe out structural discrimination thats something that well not only never get rid of its something we really rather want to have anyway

text: its joe bloggs was made redundant a year ago he has been out of work for eight months after much effort hes in the running for a job in which his rivals are a woman and a bangladeshi male his wouldbe employers tell him regretfully that although hes the right man for the job its going to the woman why because new equality legislation encourages such positive discrimination and the company has extensive contracts with government joe is outraged how can such blatant social injustice come under the banner of equality he has the backing of a large swath of public opinion in the now defunct equal opportunities commission eoc published a small scale survey less than three dozen people called talking equality from a commercial thinktank the future foundation the survey reflected the findings of the eocs own more extensive research a significant proportion of the british public believe that women receive low pay and perform a larger domestic role through choice not discrimination inequality is the result of natural differences between the sexes the findings said that equality is the concern of only a small minority of highflying females furthermore in spite of countless personal experiences of discrimination women do not see it as a major issue they regard it as a private problem with which they put up and shut up all of which means that the government has to conduct more than a couple of radio interviews if it wants to explain how and why its new and very timid equality bill is important not just for women and ethnic minorities but also for the future of joe bloggs and his children under the legislation gender pay audits will be compulsory for councils public bodies and firms which provide services for public bodies whats already known is that a woman in full time work earns p for every earned by a man if she is a graduate by the time she is without children her pay cheque will already be smaller than a man in an equivalent job if she works part time she will earn p for every earned by a man in fulltime work under the new law employers can give preferential treatment to women and ethnic minorities if equally qualified without the risk of being sued the equality bill will also outlaw age discrimination in the daily mail katja hall of the confederation of british industry says pay gaps are not the result of discrimination they are because many women prefer to work in the human resources department than the finance department or they that they prefer parttime work choice is a deceptive in this context female choice in the workplace often proceeds as follows given my priorities namely children perhaps an elderly dependent possibly a partner working long hours and inadequate or too expensive childcare what can i take thats on offer in the labour market the answer very often is one two or even three parttime jobs that underuse talent offer no career structure and pay badly but do allow you to pick kids up from school and control your hours is that a fair tradeoff critics of the new legislation argue that women are ahead academically and pouring into the professions but while they may react more quickly than their male counterparts to the starting gun once they are in the race they carry handicaps that allow the men to sprint ahead women are paid poorly because they often work in the lowlyvalued caring industry for example in residential homes they take time out to have babies and see a reduction of around in their income when they return they dont like careers fashioned in a style that suits alpha males with a wife at home mens choices also need to be opened up why should they receive only two weeks paternity pay compared with weeks for the mother why should they pay a career penalty for requesting flexible hours if they have a young child even paying them more than women means that working parttime or fewer hours is deemed unaffordable as for choosing women and ethnic minorities before men thats not fair and it hasnt been fair for the decades that men have had priority over other groups in society what this story is really about is a huge lost opportunity and the failure of both men and women to recognise a common enemy the voracious demands of the labour market the lost opportunity was back in the s when it was clear that society needed to be redesigned if talent was to be utilised and family and community life nourished in the us class actions meant that major corporations were taken to court not on behalf of one woman as here but for all women quotas were introduced that did prove successful in pushing women up the ladder faster but look at the us today women are in the workplace but the workplace is unchanged men and women work longer harder and with even less time to see one another and rear children its equality of the kind we shouldnt desire the cost is a human one but not to the bosses canada in contrast has had a much more farsighted approach to using the drive for equality as a means not of equalising misery but bringing social change since the s it has had a charter of rights and freedoms it rejects the notion that the aim is treating women the same as men formal equality it advocates that the disadvantaged require different treatment substantive equality canadian law isnt interested in the intentions of those who discriminate but it is concerned with the effects of their actions the aim is not punishment but improvement not for the individual but for the group of which she or he is a part in one case for instance women held less than of bluecollar jobs in canadian national railways the courts ordered cnr to make changes to recruitment and establish a quota system the supreme court argued that a critical mass in the workforce was essential to provide a significant chance for the continuing self correction of the system or to put it another way the more women in positions of influence perhaps the stronger the chance that parttime work wont mean the loss of a career that long hours arent always essential that family demands become more visible and companies begin to look more like the markets they are trying to reach alpha females just like alpha males will always insist on rising with the dawn chorus working hour days and hiring an army of concierges to live their lives by proxy hosting little amys birthday party choosing the wallpaper and walking the dog but for the rest of us something has to change todays front page headline in the daily mail reads women to be more equal than men it doesnt make sense and it will never be true but it strikes at a primitive and divisive fear in both men and women that this path is leading to the emasculation of men and the forfeiture of what some women regard as their femaleness explaining why this is not the case is complicated and opponents have a much easier and evocative narrative to sell in the end nobody wants a society in which men and women are forced to surrender the terrain that marks their differences so politicians have to turn the page instead of discussing these modest changes in terms of minority rights however valid they need to paint a picture of a society that uses all our talents in a variety ways allowing family life and the relationships that matter to take prominence over paid work government has to restore meaning to the word choice for fathers and mothers for some men that may mean a period of adjustment which might hurt but it will hurt less if they can see it not as women winning but as a long term gain both for themselves and those they care about most

text: harriet harmans plans for an equality bill were broadly welcomed today although the conservatives and employers questioned whether some of her specific proposals would work for the conservative party theresa may said she welcomed the plan to consolidate existing equalities legislation into one bill she criticised some of the details she said she was not sure how the proposals to tackle age discrimination in the provision of goods and services would work in practice and she said the government should concentrate on improving the pay gap in whitehall before targeting the private sector but she said the tories were committed to creating a fair and equal society and that they would work constructively with the government on the legislation but when harman made her statement in the commons backbench conservatives were more critical philip davies mp for shipley said how on earth can you justify in an equalities bill having something that allows people to be selected solely on their skin colour or gender that is completely and utterly outrageous brendan barber general secretary of the tuc described the proposed bill as a landmark piece of legislation which if implemented will help millions of people to reach their potential at work he said that the gender pay gap was in the private sector but only in the public sector using procurement to promote equality should have a major impact on promoting equality in the private sector barber said the cbis deputy directorgeneral john cridland said the cbi was in favour of the government working with employers to find ways of getting applicants from underrepresented groups into jobs but he criticised the proposals to get firms bidding for government contracts to publish equal pay audits this would be pointless and it would do nothing to improve equality in the workplace he also said the cbi was sceptical about whether it would be possible to produce workable legislation to outlaw age discrimination in the provision of goods and services stephen robertson director of the british retail consortium welcomed the governments decision not to accept union demands for all employers to carry out full equal pay audits pat healy vice president of the national pensioners convention said having equality on paper is a major step towards tackling age discrimination in society but putting that into practice is going to be much harder to achieve when the cabinet has a proportion of older people serving in it and pensioners are given proper economic power through a basic state pension then well know that ageism has really been consigned to the dustbin of history

text: the government has announced a new equality bill aimed at tackling entrenched discrimination in the workplace and beyond the bill replaces more than separate pieces of legislation covering race disability and gender equality what will it do for women although the gap between women and mens fulltime pay has fallen from in to now the government claims that unless action is taken it will take until to close the gender gap entirely the government says transparency is essential in tackling discrimination so it is banning secrecy clauses in contracts that prevent employees from talking about how much they earn this does not mean that people will be required to disclose their pay details but they can compare pay and benefits if they so choose it is also investigating the effectiveness of pay audits as a tool to close the gender pay gap although it has dropped plans to make these compulsory in the short term as part of the push for equal pay the equality and human rights commission will be launching inquiries into sectors where the gender pay gap is particularly wide including the financial sector where men earn more than their female colleagues what about positive discrimination the governments white paper says that employers will be able to take into account the makeup of their workforce when choosing between two equally qualified candidates if a particular group is underrepresented the employer can take this into account when deciding who to employ they will also be able to fasttrack or select recruits from underrepresented groups as long as they are equally suitable but they will not be allowed to promote people purely on the basis of their race or gender what about age discrimination the number of people aged over is set to double in the next years but at the moment it is quite legal for older people to be excluded from certain services or charged more simply because of their date of birth the bill outlaws age discrimination in the provision of goods and services covering everything from nhs treatment to financial services companies will no longer be able to turn down someones application for a credit card or insurance policy simply because of their age currently some insurers refuse to offer travel insurance to older consumers and some lenders have maximum age limits for mortgage customers however some things will be exempt from the rules perks such as free travel or priority flu jabs for pensioners will still be allowed and financial services companies will still be able to charge older customers more for things like insurance if there is a justifiable reason for doing so for example if they are more likely to make a claim arent there already age discrimination laws there are rules to protect people from age discrimination in the workplace the laws which were introduced in october force employers to make sure all workers have the same rights in terms of training and promotion regardless of their age they outlaw direct discrimination such as advertising for people below a certain age and indirect discrimination whereby a companys working practices have a disadvantageous effect on employees of a certain age what else is in the bill the government is considering allowing people to claim that they have been discriminated against for more than one reason at the moment you can only claim you have been treated unfairly over one characteristic for example because of your race or gender not both the government will look into the potential benefits of changing this rule it will also look into allowing trade unions and other bodies representing workers to take discrimination claims to court on behalf of a group of individuals

text: more openness about what we earn could lead to greater equality of pay there is a great deal of crossness this morning at harriet harmans equality legislation and the idea that employers might give preferential treatment to female or ethnic minority job applicants the daily mail is so angry its a wonder the paper doesnt actually combust into a smouldering pile of fury as you read it theres so much tetchiness over the possibility of positive discrimination that the other half of the story that public sector firms and private firms with publicsector contracts are going to have to reveal the salary gap between male and female employees is in danger of being overlooked which is a shame because british workers could do with a bit of focus when it comes to discussing pay put bluntly we dont do it its considered a bit crass do you know what the people sitting either side of you earn youll be in a minority if you do its not considered good office form to demand others share the figures on their pay slip in fact according to a report in the ft this morning one in four employers prevent staff from discussing pay with gagging clauses not given our general reticence on the matter that youd think theyd need them but really why shouldnt we ask your employer wont be keen of course but isnt that exactly the point it might be in their interest for you to all shut up and hope blindly that youre being paid the right amount for the job but its no good at all for the employees which would be most of us of course so go on ask the question find out how much your employer thinks youre worth in relation to your employees it might be motivating totally dispiriting or enough to make you go and work elsewhere others will say those are exactly the reasons for not doing it but actually wouldnt you rather know than just blindly slaving away

text: harriet harman said that plans being published today intended to make private companies demonstrate whether they pay male and female staff equally were designed to tackle entrenched discrimination in the workplace a bill to be unveiled in the queens speech later this year and piloted by harman labours deputy leader will require all public sector firms to publish figures showing the gender pay gap a requirement which will also be placed on firms with public sector contracts roughly of all private sector firms harman will also offer a template which private sector firms can use to publish the data although there will be no immediate statutory requirement on firms to do so ministers will consider secondary legislation at some point a white paper being published today will outline the plans which will also allow employers to give preferential treatment to female or ethnic minority job candidates and which will outlaw age discrimination in the provision of goods and services interviewed about her plans on bbc radio s today programme harman strongly rejected the idea that as one newspaper headline suggested she was trying to make women more equal than men women more equal than men chance would be a fine thing she said parttime women receive less pay than fulltime men do you think that thats because they are less intelligent less committed less hardworking less qualified its not the case under the plans public sector employers and private sector firms with public sector contracts will be expected to publish the percentage difference in the average pay of men and women in the company but not the actual amount although other private firms will not initially be compelled to publish the figures harman said she thought the new regime would challenge the secrecy culture surrounding pay firms that did not publish the figures would look as if they had something to hide she went on we have structural discrimination on pay we will be able to see it clearly for the first time workplace by workplace and then women will be able see that they are paid less than men and they will be able to complain about it and challenge it harman said that her plans would not force employers to discriminate against men but she said that where candidates were equally qualified it would allow employers to hire female or ethnic minority candidates without fear of being sued for discrimination she said the government needed to legislate because the law on this subject was currently not clear the new rules would be permissive she pointed out labour had used this kind of positive discrimination to bring about a dramatic increase in the number of women in parliament and she said the new rules would help police forces trying to recruit more black or asian officers the white paper will also outlaw discrimination in goods and services on the basis of age a measure likely to cost the department of health billions of pounds if it is to fulfil a new duty to end discrimination on the basis of age in healthcare the department will publish research today revealing the scale of discrimination in the provision of health alongside an estimate of the cost of ending it a government source said age discrimination is the last major frontier whereby it is all right to say sorry you are past it so i am not going to provide you with insurance or health services however insurance premiums for older people will continue to be higher on the basis that it is actuarially justified in her interview harman said public authorities would have a duty not to discriminate on the grounds of age we have been criticised for being a nanny state i think we need to be a bit of a granny state she said whitehall officials have prepared research for the government showing the gender pay gap in the treasury is the department for transport defra the department for culture the department for communities and the department for work and pensions in the government equalities office women are paid more than men the figures are dated from the end of the equalities bill will also introduce rights for breastfeeding mothers to feed their babies in public and end discrimination in private member clubs that bar women the liberal democrat equality spokeswoman lynne featherstone said if the government genuinely wants to tackle equality it must do more to end the growing discrepancy between the rules on pay for the public and private sector without compulsory pay audits for the private sector these proposals will represent a very real victory for the hawks in the cabinet public sector equality rights are fast becoming an ivory tower that private sector employees can only dream of a few tickbox questionnaires for government suppliers on their equality policy are going to do little to change the daytoday opportunities for the million people who work in the private sector unison the public services union called on harman to fund equal pay in local authorities who are not facing up to their legal responsibilities

text: i cant tell people what is happening at home a new report by the nspcc draws long overdue attention to the plight of south asian children not just as victims of violence but as witnesses it highlights the cultural context isolation fear of racism language barriers uncertain immigration status cultural and religious pressures to keep the marriage going which means that asian women on average take years to leave a violent relationship thus exposing their children to substantial psychological and physical damage once a woman makes that leap what awaits her are underfunded overcrowded asian womens refuges what might stop her accessing even these services are nervous social workers police officers and teachers who are hindered by political correctness says the nspcc from intervening in asian cultural practices this is not new it is not so much political correctness but the ideology of multiculturalism that has given rise to this situation tolerance of cultural practices by state agencies has been going on since at least the s black feminists have campaigned hard against this aspect of multiculturalism which has given unelected community leaders autonomy in the domestic cultural and religious affairs of the community for a mainstream organisation like the nspcc to lend its weight to the issue adds impetus to the critique as a result of campaigning and the victoria climbi case there have been substantial shifts in policy guidelines based on the underlying principle that multicultural sensitivity is not an excuse for moral blindness were drawn up by the government to enable schools and other agencies to deal sensitively with issues like forced marriage the report rightly identifies this as a concern for asian women and girls as implementation has been patchy the government has finally agreed to put these guidelines on a statutory basis in the autumn that will allow ngos to hold state agencies accountable although the uneven delivery of services is still an issue the fact that the nspcc has highlighted this as its big conclusion feels curiously outdated because the debate has changed multiculturalism came under attack in the cantle report in into the race riots in bradford and was further discredited in the wake of the bombings in the governments war against terror building cohesion has become the new holy grail within this policy construct singlegroup funding has fallen out of favour paradoxically the funding of muslim groups continues apace while secular groups are being hit specialist organisations catering for those vulnerable groups at the centre of the nspcc report are to have their funding cut southall black sisters struggle to replace the core funding under threat of withdrawal by ealing council is one of the most widely publicised examples of this the nspcc makes a welcome case for the continuing need for a specialist sector but fails to make the links it is this failure that takes the nspcc report into dangerous territory when it calls for the engagement of faith and community leaders in the fight against domestic violence it is precisely these leaders who act as gatekeepers to the community and cry racist when the state intervenes who account for the nervousness of state agencies the nspcc organised a conference aimed at the muslim community which was attended by imams it found unsurprisingly that for some imams the issue of domestic abuse is not on their radar perhaps the most telling statement of all was that many mosques are the premises of men only in the teeth of such entrenched patriarchal attitudes calling for the training of imams feels like trying to empty a lake with a teacup when the muslim parliament of great britain reported on the extent of child abuse in madrasas in little action was taken in this new political climate minority girls rights are again being sold down the river the political correctness the nspcc highlights is about to get worse commander steve allen of the metropolitan police at a recent conference on domestic violence said the governments agenda on terror is hampering police work on issues such as forced marriage because the government is keen not to alienate those same leaders in the fight against extremism perhaps we need the kind of research that demonstrates how children exposed to violence develop a tendency to extremism as adults before the government will show greater commitment to minority women rahila gupta is a member of southall black sisters and author of enslaved the new british slavery rahiliaguptayahoocouk this article was amended on tuesday july rahila gupta is a member of the management committee for southall black sisters not a founder as we said in the footnote above this has been corrected

text: its not often a window is opened into the lives of couples who try to be truly equal recently the new york times sunday magazine featured a cover story on mothers and fathers who share parenting and household duties equally in which there are no mommy jobs and no daddy jobs mommy has to put kids before career and so does daddy the author lisa belkin described these parents founding principles they would create their own model one in which they were parenting partners equals and peers neither would be the keeper of the mental todo lists neither of their careers would take precedence when it comes to marriage the more things change the less things change in a society where mothers who work fulltime still do twice the amount of housework and even more childcare hours as working fathers the idea that dad would give up his career advancement to cook with the kids is pretty radical when we define equality for adult women and men we usually use breadwinning as the key indicator at home meanwhile this mother puts it best when she says someone has to be in charge that someone is usually mom a fact that hasnt changed in decades look we say a mother can work too and keep bringing home the bacon even though shes also staying up late to clean the house and take care of the children thats not equality thats taking on an extra job these social norms change slowly but we see more examples each day and now in barack and michelle obama we have a fantastic opportunity for american leaders to model change as psychologists say michelle has told us barack forgets to pick up his socks but most of their communication both verbal and nonverbal even the famous fist jab signals he and michelle are equal partners starting now i hope they show us how for many myself included to be frank its challenging to see men in these nurturing roles it goes against so many of our cultural norms we need leaders to model new norms for us amy vachon a shared care parent featured in the new york times article states that the philosophy of being teammates is more important than how tasks break down and though his career clearly hasnt suffered the obamas with their international stage can offer insight into how to manage an equal partnership its successes and failures while much is made of obamas new masculinity a nonmartial viewpoint his sensitivity and gestalt openly informed by a matriarchy this is not a person who worked parttime so he could plan sashas play dates and clean the house but nor is michelle who was the breadwinner for many years the obamas have offered us a rare frank snapshot of their relationship but i want to know more i would love to know how these two superachievers did it because right now i see michelle holding the lions share of the household duties and that is equality version not michelle has gotten a lot of flak for describing her husband but i recognize this loving selfdeprecation as banter between equals imagine if hillary clinton had had the guts to rib bill a little back in defending her comments about baracks difficulty picking up after himself michelle said in an interview in glamour magazine people understood that this is how we all live in our marriages and barack is very much human so lets not deify him because what we do is we deify and then were ready to chop it down yes lets not deify the great man but lets also not deify the ideal of the milllennial mom she who has cut back her schedule but remains high powered attends mommy and me yoga and uses her professional skills to run the house like a corporation michelle obamas comments can verge on this and while it rings too true for many women its not where we need to be in iowa this winter michelle told audiences her husband is snorey and stinky in the morning doesnt put the butter back in the fridge and one morning put on his clothes and left while she juggled her own schedule to deal with an overflowing toilet writing in the wall street journal monica langley noted that michelle obama expects a lot of every family member from having her six and nineyearold daughters set their own alarm clocks to insisting her husband pick up his dirty socks obama has spoken of the importance of fathers and his own pain that his own father opted out of his life he speaks of the importance of being a truly present father attentive sensitive and engaged nicely said barack but i would like to hear how you helped michelle maintain her career i want details did you compromise anything did you ever miss a critical meeting come home from the legislature in springfield and stay up late doing something around the house michelle has spoken of her struggles when obama served in the illinois state senate and one gets the sense she shouldered almost all the parenting burden while maintaining a very fulltime job what a role model the obamas could be to the millions of couples out there trying to figure out how to maintain a true partnership when the kids come along and compromises must be made if barack is a new kind of man as pundits are fond of saying perhaps he can show us hes a new kind of husband as well

text: something happened last week that few papers reported on and which few of us would really grasp as significant in any way the un security council unanimously adopted resolution which said that sexual violence in conflict zones is a matter of international peace and security so what rape has always happened in war since time immemorial hasnt it our history books are littered with phrases such as the spoils of war or rape and pillage as though rape is a normal byproduct of any conflict a female interviewee involved in amnesty international research in sudan said janjawid militia and government soldiers attacked a primary school for girls raping the pupils they were aged between and because i told people what happened the authorities arrested me they said we will show you what rape is a teacher from gitega burundi interviewed for an amnesty international report said i was stopped by an officer of the government armed forces and taken to a military base in mubugua the soldier raped me and kept me with him all night this was just common practice i had a child from the rape and we have lots of difficulties to the extent that resolution was reported on at all it was hailed for recognising rape as a war crime but rape already was a war crime it was just we never took it seriously or treated it as such even in the customary laws of war the geneva conventions of and a host of other human rights treaties rape was at least implicitly recognised as a human rights abuse a grave breach and in some circumstances a war crime the rome statute a result of much womens activism and the tribunals of rwanda and yugoslavia achieved prosecutions for rape as a war crime then came resolution in that was meant to put women at the heart of the peace and reconstruction processes indeed resolutions and now bear many similarities so what is new about resolution resolution doesnt just say rape is a bad thing it says that crimes of sexual violence committed during conflict particularly those committed systematically as a weapon or tactic of war to terrorise humiliate and wipe out or forcibly relocate whole communities prolongs deepens and promotes conflict such crimes especially if they are not addressed or punished linger in the minds structure and makeup of whole communities the systemic use of rape on communities emotionally physically and financially damages both the individuals and these communities for years to come they feed anger vengeance and distrust and so fuel continued cycles of conflict displacement and refugee flows the resolution makes a direct link between such crimes of sexual violence and conflicts that may rumble on for years or erupt again years later that is to say the use of rape and sexual violence as weapon of war is a matter of national and international security and must be factored into the planning decisions and strategies of international peace and security its a political issue as well to those of us working text: we had been married for less than an hour and my wife was already asking me for a divorce we shouldnt have done that got married youre probably right but we dont need a divorce theres another thing we can have a different thing well get one of those you mean an annulment my wife was right i did mean an annulment but i couldnt think of the word because i was drunk we were sitting in a bus shelter opposite a hollywood wedding chapel in an area on the seedier side of las vegas passing a bottle of jack daniels between us first in celebration then in desperation to the passerby we looked seriously in need of an annulment well blame it on the drink i said people will understand of course people didnt actually know we were getting married in the first place most didnt even know we were a couple in the space of a month we had met fallen in love got drunk stayed drunk and eloped one minute we were slumped in a pub in london the next we were slumped in a bus shelter in vegas talking about a divorce sorry an annulment i had never seen myself as the marrying type much of my late teenage years and early s was spent in a ramshackle fashion i was either dropping in and out of college or lurching from one lowgrade job to a lesser one in some sort of anticareer move as my s progressed my appetite for any sort of career declined i moved to spain where i worked in bars loafed around reading books and played chess i was happy to be more or less single and determined to stay that way my lifestyle already mimicked that of a retiree and i was pretty much happy i used to have an idea in my head that this is how cliff richard would have lived if he hadnt been able to sing and if he had tendencies towards alcoholism still things changed out of nowhere i got the opportunity to write a book writing for a living had always been an ambition of mine albeit one that had never been realised due to a lack of talent and an everevaporating sense of discipline but here was my chance a friend had put me in contact with a countess in italy who wanted someone to pen her memoirs in return for accommodation board and a slice of the potential profits emails and phone calls somehow convinced her of my credentials and ability and i was to fly to rome to spend several months recording her story and writing about her in the meantime i was to go to london to drum up support from my contacts in the publishing industry of which i had none and prepare for writing the book of which i was incapable love in the form of celia got in the way she was a friend and colleague of my brother they had done their phds at the same university and the first time we met in a pub in london i fell for her immediately and completely she was smart as a whip funny pretty and kind for the first time i felt comfortable being with someone and being me rather than either an exaggerated or dampened down version of me for a month we had a straightoutofthemovies love affair looking back it seems that every day during that beginning bit of the summer was sunny that every stranger doffed their cap as i passed that every time i looked in the mirror my smiling face looked back at me of course all thats probably rubbish the first stages of love are often full of horror and uncertainty and i variously felt scared and guilty scared because she was a doctor and i was a tramp and guilty because she had just come out of a fiveyear relationship and i was a newly found really terrible biographer who may have been taking advantage of her there was a lot of sneaking around that month and a lot of emotion and it all became too much we split up then got back together again then split up then between us we decided it would be a good idea to get married the idea sprang out of nowhere one evening in the pub neither of us had ever fancied a traditional wedding and we thought if we did it where no one could see then if things didnt work out it could be our secret we booked flights and a hotel and then without either our bags or our minds got on an airplane from what ive heard our experience of vegas differed from most peoples for a start there was very little whooping i cant remember either of us giving anyone a high five we were fairly subdued the bright lights didnt exactly set our souls on fire flying across the world to marry someone is all very well as an idea in a pub to actually be in that talked about place in the flesh ready to do the thing after four weeks of knowing each other is an altogether different prospect what the hell did we think we were doing and who the hell did we think we were we shouldnt do this would be our mantra for one hour yes we should would be our mantra for the next in the end we did i bought a threepack of white tshirts for myself and a white dress for my wifetobe we looked at wedding chapels and decided on a hollywood wedding chapel because it was one of the first listed in the phone book and because the whole thing could be done for about the day we got married was hot and we spent it doing the two things that had become customary during our relationship drinking and soul searching our chapel was opposite a rundown bar where we chatted with the toothless locals and bought them all shots it got to about seven oclock lets go and get married said celia the actual service lasted about three minutes and except for the vicar and one of the staff there was no one to witness it back on the street it was just us with the jack daniels and talk of annulments a shade less than an hour after being pronounced man and wife perhaps the story should end there dont get married to a virtual stranger could be the message it will ruin your life but it didnt we came back to london and gradually family and friends found out we were treated to weeks of astonishment anger confusion and congratulations some more genuine than others i hope you know what youre doing was a phrase we heard more than once the thing was did we know what we were doing what exactly were we playing at gradually the novelty of being newly married gave way to grim reality i felt like i was wrong in everything the way i behaved the way i thought it was unfair on my family not to have told them it was unfair on celia that she had married such a waster it was unfair to my loner sensibilities that i had entered into a lifelong commitment that winter in london i underwent the biggest comedown imaginable i was poor unemployable and married to a doctor i had no career history no qualifications and i felt in her shadow i spent many sleepless nights wondering what i was going to do the whole thing felt insane i had two choices to run away like i had done from every other bad situation in my life or stay and fight for my marriage i surprised myself and plumped for the latter now some two years later we are still married its been a slog financially and emotionally but in the main a very happy one ive realised that theres a reason why people get to know each other first and then plan to get married weve had to do it the other way around getting to know each other and going through the teething process of an early relationship after we had already made that commitment but we made it through and somehow ive managed to forge a career as a journalist thanks to unwavering support kindness and belief from my wife when i was at my lowest ebb to be able to start the day without a pint a panic attack or a bout of selfloathing has been a revelation ive realised that my ambition to make a living as a writer has always been there but i was happy to cover it up by taking on menial work drinking myself to sleep every night and pretending i was happy i honestly cant thank her enough both for helping me turn my life around and showing me what love really is even when she barely knew me it will take the rest of my life to begin to pay her back what we had a couple of years ago was a wedding what we have now is a marriage i suppose the world is littered with stories of people who have married on a whim and lived to regret it you could say that we were selfish and irresponsible at the time and the fact that our marriage has not only survived but also flourished is something of a fluke i dont like that argument i think we got married and stayed married because on some level we knew we were just about right for each other we were in love if i could have my time over again i wouldnt change a thing despite what was said during that sad desperate hour in the bus shelter i hope i think my wife feels the same way viva text: lessons about honourbased violence and forced marriage should be an explicit statutory requirement in british schools and become a compulsory part of the sex and relationships curriculum mps said today a report from the allparty home affairs select committee said education on these issues seemed to be at best variable and at worst nonexistent with some schools apparently resistant to discussing them owing to fear of offending parents and communities it said there was evidence to suggest that children were in danger of being removed from school or further education and forced into marriage the committee acknowledged the significant steps taken to stop domestic and honourbased violence however it criticised the governments disproportionate focus on the criminal justice system committee chairman keith vaz said we are still failing victims in different ways through a shortage of refuge space through the ignorance or disbelief of professionals or by allowing the continued abuse of some of those forced into marriage by granting visas to their spouses there needed to be a shift in focus towards education prevention and early intervention he added we educate our young people about the dangers of drugs or road safety but not it seems about domestic and honourbased violence and forced marriage which will affect a quarter of all women in their lifetime and many men too posters and other publicity material should be sent out to schools by the department for children schools and families rather than waiting for a specific request from teachers the report said the mps also suggested there should be a wideranging public education campaign about all the issues involved in domestic violence along the lines of a road safety campaign and that doctors and nurses should undergo training in identifying victims of domestic violence other recommendations include a specialised victim protection programme similar to witness protection for women fleeing honourbased violence and refusing visa applications in the case of reluctant brides or bridegrooms domestic violence cost the uk bn in in terms of expenses incurred on public services losses to the economy and costs to the victim the report said with the true cost likely to be much higher as not all crimes are reported to police yesterday saw the second in a series of national roadshows organised by the government to tackle honourbased violence the event in cambridge brought together police officials from the crown prosecution service and charities to raise awareness of the problem the home office minister vernon coaker described honourbased violence as a heinous crime that had no place in society i recognise the scale of the problem is largely unknown since so much of it remains underground these roadshows will help authorities identify the problem more readily helping some of the most vulnerable people in the country the governments forced marriage unit deals with inquiries and cases of forced marriage every year about a third of these concern unders and are men home office figures suggest there are about honour killings each year but the report says the total is likely to be far text: some revolutions take longer to arrive than others several thousand years of assumptions about the rights of women were never going to disappear overnight as is illustrated by the glacially slow pace of progress of women in public life since womens suffrage was granted years ago some inequalities have taken longer to tackle than others violence against women particularly at home has been all the more difficult to tackle societys unspoken assumption that the victim must be in some way to blame is taking time to shake off hard to detect and harder to escape from whether it is in the form of coercion into marriage or a drunken beating by a violent partner professionals are slow to uncover it less than one complaint in ends in conviction its sheer invisibility is part of the problem worldwide more women between the ages of and die from domestic violence than any other cause even road accidents or cancer in britain two women a week are killed by a partner or family member hundreds more experience some level of physical or emotional violence although celebrities such as gordon and tana ramsay have run the london marathon to raise money for campaigning charities like womens aid public awareness of the nature and extent of it is still low that makes todays report from mps on the crossparty home affairs committee a milestone in the way domestic violence is approached taking a broad sweep it has produced a compendium that assesses the progress of the past decade and charts a way forward for the next one this should be challenging reading for a government that prides itself on what has been done since it highlights the problems of leaving service provision to cashstrapped local councils with dozens of different priorities and a reluctance to tackle a subject that can be a cultural nightmare the result is an uneven and often inadequate range of services and a chronic shortage of places in refuges and of the specialist workers who support the women and children in them most specialist childrens workers are not sponsored by public funds at all while the mps report singles out the fate of one of the leading specialist providers southall black sisters which hangs in the balance because its local authority has withdrawn funding meanwhile visas are still granted to men who have made forced marriages to young british women and uncertain numbers of girls disappear from schools every week possibly in retaliation for refusing to obey their parents yet schools have no obligation to pursue them or register their fate what is needed now is a set of national standards and the cash to fund them

text: womens rights campaigners tried last night to forestall a feared cabinet decision to water down a government commitment to end gender discrimination in the workplace in a letter to the guardian today the uks biggest unions and poverty charities say ministers must be bold brave and decisive in tackling the yawning pay gap between women and men the cabinets domestic affairs committee is due this week to decide what to include in an equality bill in the queens speech later this year ministers have discussed proposals to make large firms conduct equal pay audits to discover any hidden discrimination that could explain why women earn less but the womens rights organisation the fawcett society said the economic downturn means the government is more reluctant to impose extra burdens on industry katherine rake the societys director said we are keen that ministers do not shortchange women because they fear there will be a business backlash the letter drafted by the society is signed by leaders of unite unison and the gmb as well as the child poverty action group it says the pay gap means on average women earn a year less than men the equivalent of men being paid all year and women working for free from october the treasury set a target in for of large employers to complete an equal pay review by april but the government has not disclosed the outcome womens rights campaigners want equal pay audits to be mandatory within five years if companies do not make adequate progress on a voluntary basis a government spokeswoman said ministers were considering the contents of the equality bill and hoped to be able to comment shortly

text: changing our terminology wont stop mass killings i know that but it might go some way toward more fully comprehending and better campaigning against some of the worst atrocities of our time just as genocide refers to a systematic killing of a race or ethnicity so gendercide refers to the systematic killing of a gender although amnesty international and other groups have been right to push for the term femicide to describe the murder of hundreds of women in ciudad jurez in mexico and guatemala city on the whole itd be more helpful to use the more neutral term gendercide to help raise awareness of the issue as evidently the victims are not always women one such case is srebrenica the subject of renewed analysis although it shouldnt take a news story to remind us of it after the capture of karadzic last week it is widely acknowledged that the killing of bosnian men and boys was part of a policy to kill as many noncombatant males as possible in order to reduce the pool of possible enemy soldiers recognising that this was a gendercide is completely compatible with recognising that it was a genocide a fact which has been long established the victims of srebrenica and similar massacres ordered by karadzic were targeted because of their ethnicity but they were also targeted because of their gender to refer to srebrenica as a gendercide doesnt imply that one genders suffering in a war was somehow more important than the other side linda grants recent piece on rape as a weapon of war in bosnia is a reminder of how women were brutally targeted throughout the conflict but when a rape occurs during peacetime we tend to think of it as a violent misogynistic act when a rape occurs during war time we tend to think of it as a violent racist act an atrocity motivated by the ethnicity of the victim we need to start recognising that war is gendered in reality that in this arena women are not raped solely for being women or solely for their ethnicity but for the combination of the two for me feminism has always been about how rigid gender roles harm everyone albeit primarily women and during a war rigid gender roles like rigid ethnic stereotypes lead to a differentiated targeting of civilians one counterargument i anticipate in reply to this is that as gendercide is a less potent phrase than genocide in part by virtue of it still being largely unknown using it may seem to belittle the genocide committed in bosnia but no one is arguing that gender is the main reason for the mass murders in most cases although it does seem to be the primary element in the gendercides of ciudad jurez and guatemala city it was however an element of the mass killings in bosnia and we ignore it at our peril as a whole we have little framework for the concept of intersecting discriminations and until we can formulate a succinct way of expressing the multidimensional nature of oppression to refer to srebrenica as a genocide and a gendercide may be the best way we can convey the various aspects that were at work rather than belittling mass killings moreover using the phrase gendercide in other contexts has the opposite effect it becomes an important way to convey the true scale and nature of genderbased murders which are otherwise often dismissed as a conglomerate of discrete phenomena the product of a few bad eggs until we routinely conceptualise the murders of women in guatemala city and ciudad jurez as gendercides as killings directed specifically against one section of a population the tragedies will continue to be dismissed as essentially random acts its hard to account for the shocking police impunity to the murders in jurez but it seems that the mexican polices position is essentially that a few men happen to kill some women and thats all very sad but not something society as a whole should feel responsible for or be concerned about the evocation of the word genocide in the word gendercide the implication that like genocide it is a crime against humanity for which there are no excuses would also counter the deadend cultural relativism that feminists have to deal with from across the spectrum whenever they speak out against genderbased violence one of the things that is so frustrating about cultural relativism is not its central philosophical tenet so much as the fact it is used so inconsistently by its proponents no one i hope ever says of apartheid south africa well that was just their culture who are we to judge the systematic oppression of a whole race is not a legitimate part of anyones culture but the systematic oppression of a gender whenever i raise the topic of countries whose treatment of women could largely be termed a gender apartheid the response in liberal circles is well thats their culture lets not be imperialist as though apartheid was a temporal historical act within the reach of our moral judgment whereas culture must be treated as an innate ahistorical phenomena which renders it impossible to judge why do gender roles get pushed into the playpen of culture beyond time and beyond criticism when ethnicity it is accepted is a constructed identity that changes over time defined and redefined and manipulated by ultranationalists like karadzic is the murder of female children in india and china more forgivable on the grounds of culture than the mass murder of ethnic groups surely unless youre prepared to stand up and admit yes i think it is worse to discriminate on the grounds of race than on gender then gendercide is as legitimate a phrase as genocide and we should be as ready to speak out against it as we are against racial or ethnicitybased violence as karadzic is finally brought to justice i hope we take into account all the dimensions of the mass killings he and mladic ordered so that we can finally begin to make sense of what happened in bosnia and prevent it from happening again

text: when the womens domestic violence and abuse charity southall black sisters sbs was threatened with the loss of its core funding earlier this year its chairwoman pragna patel received letters from service users a third of the women patel says stated that they were suicidal and could not cope without the groups support while letters is a modest amount for mainstream charity it speaks volumes for a specialist black and minority ethnic bme group that provides services and support for women who often lack not only the literacy skills it takes to write a letter but also the freedom to walk to the post box to send it the predicament sbs found itself in was caused by the london borough of ealings threat to withdraw its annual grant to the charity after deciding last year to commission a boroughwide domestic violence service rather than a specialist one it appeared that the domestic and sexual violence charity had fallen victim to a shift in policy driven by last years governmentbacked commission on integration and cohesion cic report which suggested that singlegroup funding meaning grants from public bodies to for example womens groups and ethnic minorityled organisations were inimical to the principles of cohesion and should be the exception not the rule now however after two sbs service users brought about a judicial review of the councils decision patel is able to inform her service users that her group has won a reprieve ealing council effectively conceded defeat at the hearing this month by withdrawing from the case and agreeing to reconsider its commissioning of domestic violence services the outcome will be welcomed by many small specialist bme community groups and charities which have been concerned that the new cohesion agenda will squeeze key funding sources at the hearing lord justice moses was told that the council had failed to assess the adverse impact on bme women of its decision to replace a specialist service with a generic one louise whitfield the public law project solicitor who represented sbs successfully argued that ealing failed to carry out a full and proper race equality impact assessment the move left no safety net for vulnerable women whose cases were made more complex by language difficulties and cultural pressures as well as immigration and asylum difficulties sbs receives inquiries a year from women in need mosess comments about the general cohesion agenda have potentially massive ramifications for local government and specialist third sector services and how the former funds the latter he said there is no dichotomy between funding specialist services and cohesion equality is necessary for cohesion to be achieved unprincipled approach patel describes the case as a key moment for the third sector she says were delighted with the outcome as if wed lost it would not only be a setback for our organisations but for others we felt that the councils approach was so unprincipled that we had no choice but to fight it kevin curley chief executive of the national association for voluntary and community action navca says the case has serious implications the judge linked the funding of specialised services with community cohesion he says here we have a judge saying that whereas the government has been suggesting for a long time that separate funding for blackled organisations will undermine cohesion and reinforces segregation if you do not publicly fund blackled groups then organisations retreat into themselves and have to spend a lot of time generating funding i think it is likely if they see socalled community facilities open to the whole community receiving public funding those will be whiteled organisations and it can breed resentment and segregation the sbs case has implications for local authorities whitfield adds it is important to make councils understand that there is more to cohesion than generic services and to understand that when they are meeting their duties under the race relations act they have got to listen to what users and groups have to say she stresses had we not had the case and there was not the strength of feeling and lobbying lots of councils would be saying we shouldnt fund single groups anymore and that is hugely problematic arjumand kazmi head of policy at bme third sector network group voice change england agrees that the case means there is even greater onus on councils to comply with race equality legislation especially in undertaking race equality impact assessments councils will need to make funding decisions based on evidenced need and not to make assumptions about communities needs in its defence ealing council says it never argued that community cohesion and integration were in conflict with specialist funding council leader jason stacey adds ealing council defended this case because it believes that all women in the borough regardless of their ethnic background should have equal access to domestic violence services this principle remains but the process has highlighted areas of the law that are unclear and open to many different interpretations stacey believes that the case will now give local authorities muchneeded guidance on grant aid funding and the council withdrew from the case on that basis we shall now be inviting the equality and human rights commission ehrc to assist us in refining our equality impact assessment process and this will benefit all councils he says ealing council also agreed to pay the costs of the charitys legal representation and those of the ehrc which supported the case sbs estimates the costs could be as much as the same amount as the annual grant however as well as forcing councils to rethink their approach to specialist funding and how they carry out their equalities assessments some observers believe that ultimately the government must rework the cic suggestions and guidelines on specialist group funding jess crocker local advocate with the national council for voluntary organisations compact advocacy programme says we welcome the outcome of this case as it provides legal backing for the many calls from the voluntary sector for government to revise its thinking on cohesion as the judge rightly points out specialist services can help communities to bond and councils must not shirk their duties to minority groups in the name of the cohesion agenda kazmi agrees we would like the department for communities and local government dclg in partnership with the office of the third sector and the bme third sector to produce an equality and cohesion guidance for funders explaining the clear evidenced links between inequality discrimination and disadvantage mixed messages for curley the governments lack of tight guidelines has given local authorities carte blanche to use singlegroup funding as an excuse to claw back the cash from specialist organisations he says if the government was asserting the fact that investing local government money in specialist blackled services was good for service users and cohesion and race relations then i think local authorities would tread very carefully before risking political flak in taking money away from proven and good quality services but if the government is giving mixed messages or suggesting that funding for black organisations undermines cohesion it arms them to go down a route they would otherwise have been wary of for its part the dclg says it is up to local authorities to determine how they allocate funding to specific groups or issues in their local area depending on local needs a spokesman adds we will of course review any judgments reached in this case to check whether they have any relevance the local government association lga meanwhile believes that it has already made clear that there are circumstances where singlegroup funding can help to promote cohesion all local authorities should have regard to equalities legislation and best practice when they review funding relationships with voluntary organisations says a spokesman the lga will consider any judgment made as a result of this case once it is available whitfield says that in the last six months she has been contacted by around different specialist organisations not just in relation to race some in relation to gender asking whether or not they can challenge their local council for cutting their funding because of the singlegroup funding policy the sbs case rather than bringing to an end the controversy has simply opened a new chapter in the longrunning debate on specialist funding this is going to go on whitfield warns this is the first skirmish and it will shake a lot of councils
