text: women working full time will be paid less than their male counterparts over their lifetime it was claimed yesterday as new government figures emerged showing that the gender pay gap has widened over the past year men are now paid more than women for fulltime work a slight increase on last year while the disparity in parttime wages is up from in according to the office of national statistics annual survey of hours and earnings that lifetime disparity would be enough to pay for years of childcare or new cars the equality and human rights commission estimated or to pay off the average student debt times over katherine rake director of the fawcett society called the ons figures dire news for women after years of painfully slow progress in closing the pay gap we have now actually gone into reverse gear with the pay gap widening over for women working full and part time this sadly demonstrates that the government has failed to take serious action to combat discrimination still facing women in the labour market the world economic forum found this week that the uk had dropped from th to th in the global gender equality league table with sri lanka in th the annual survey ranks countries in terms of equality of economic participation access to education and healthcare and political empowerment that survey placed britain st in the world in terms of progress on equal pay for similar work with sri lanka places above rake said the worst offender on unequal pay is the financial sector where salaries and bonuses can remain widely disproportionate between the sexes but she also pointed to small companies without dedicated human resources facilities which are less likely to conduct pay audits the fawcett society has called on the government to include mandatory pay auditing in the equalities bill scheduled to be introduced in next months queens speech harriet harman the minister for women and equality has already announced a requirement for all public sector bodies to publish their gender pay gaps the figure for the treasury is though women in the government equalities office are paid more than men sri lankas position above britain in the global equality chart can also be explained in part by its high ranking on political empowerment the country is judged the fifth most equal in the world thanks to the long incumbencies as prime minister and president of sirimavo bandaranaike and chandrika kumaratunga the widow and daughter respectively of the assassinated prime minister swrd bandaranaike britains score dipped slightly on this index thanks to a fall in the number of women ministers yvonne galligan director of the centre for the advancement of women in politics at queens university in belfast said it was a matter of concern that there were still fewer than women in the house of commons its very interesting to look at the scottish parliament and the welsh assembly in both there is a much healthier gender balance and that has meant that issues come into the political arena that are perhaps seen as womens issues but are adopted collectively she cited the issue of violence against women which she said had been strongly taken up by the scottish parliament in general she said younger parliaments were often much more representative the rwandan parliament is the first where women outnumber men but dr selvi thriuchandran director of the womens education and research centre in the sri lankan capital of colombo said she was puzzled by the wef findings pointing out that aside from the bandaranaikes sri lanka had the worst record in text: what do women want in a man it is the eternal question and it has never been answered well this week i stumbled across the answer completely by mistake of course women of my grandmothers generation seem to settle for someone who can carry a heavy watering can who can take them for a run out in the car for a pasty and chips at a push someone who can iron their own shirts for my mothers text: why do young people understand so little about the world of work friday sees a government initiative encouraging children to take over various workplaces around the country for a day organised by the childrens commissioners office the idea is that by allowing children to be mini decisionmakers for a day they will understand a little more about what goes on at work sounds fun sounds noisy but this is a serious purpose for years employers and their various organisations have complained that the graduates they hire are bright and able just not ready for work where do the roots of this problem lie are parents to blame for not telling their kids what they do all day i visited three primary schools in north staffordshire to find out i asked children of all ages from schools with very different catchments areas what their parents did they all knew often in startling detail fouryearold daniel from leek first school explained my mum works at home she looks after henry and baby brooke henry is his younger brother and mum is a childminder to the baby nineyearold matthew interprets his fathers solicitor job as my dad helps people to treat other people better his father is in fact the senior partner olivia six said her father worked in a fish and chip shop selling fish sausages chips and drinks she had no idea he owned the shop likewise sixyearold george said his dad was a plumber and my mum gives cups of coffee to people working in our house in fact his parents run their own heating repair business many children expressed great pride in their parents jobs racheljay from churnet view middle school beamed that her mum is a very very good dinner lady and a brilliant cook and when robert said my dad teaches canoeing climbing and cycling at a climbing centre his classmates cheered declaring this a great job at westwood first school several children i met had direct experience of work megan eight told me my dad works in a shop called antiques within delivering fixing and selling things i know this because sometimes i go to work with him eightyearold daniel said my dad works in a scrap merchants buying and selling scrap ive also been to his work daughter of a vicar anna eight had a clear idea of his role he has meetings with married couples and sometimes he works at home doing stuff for the church time and again it was their parents jobs in relation to other people that the children homed in on they liked being asked about it and they knew the details that to them mattered status and hierarchy were not just unimportant they simply didnt exist but fast forward another dozen years and employers complaints about the young graduates theyve recruited go beyond literacy and numeracy skills something more fundamental is missing says richard wainer the cbis head of education and skills policy we wouldnt say every graduate is unfit for work but generic skills are often lacking such as team building communication skills and problem solving its a view echoed by john mcgurk of the chartered institute of personnel and development though he grimaces at calling these soft skills tactical skills is a better term it comes from the armed forces where the idea that only officers should learn these skills is frowned upon because if the person in charge is killed someone has to take over if people skills are lacking among some graduates its not the parents who are to blame but the fault of employers themselves who place too much emphasis on the paper chase for qualifications so says occupational psychologist and careers adviser sherridan hughes everyone has to have the obligatory these days and many employers look for good alevel grades too little wonder that students get the idea that academic achievement is all that matters its gone too far were losing good young people as a result kids are killing themselves getting these pieces of paper workrelated learning is a statutory element at key stage four of the national curriculum and almost all to yearolds undertake work experience lasting one or two weeks but is that really sufficient often its just a token gesture where kids just make the tea or do the filing and very few really get valuable experience says hughes a view echoed by mcgurk work experience is often a tickbox exercise which doesnt involve proper engagement beyond showing someone the photocopier so children lose interest it has to be properly structured and many arent so theyre next to useless the uks system of one short work placement doesnt measure up well in international comparisons says tony watts visiting professor in career development at the university of derby in sweden school pupils used to complete three placements over a period of time and across three sectors manufacturing service and social services he says thats no longer the case but it had the merit of giving all young people experience in a variety of work generally speaking tracking work in school is stronger in most scandinavian and european systems than here it could be because we have a different culture that encourages education to be less vocational than in europe half of all the graduate vacancies advertised in the uk are for graduates in any subject quite a striking statistic a spokesman at the department for children schools and families says the new curriculum which started this september has more enterprise and business skills content the new curriculum is designed to be less prescriptive and more flexible so teachers can encourage children to use the kind of skills employers have said are missing says the spokesman who explains that changes to the curriculum and the new diploma qualification include more workbased training too schools dont exist as entities in themselves we recognise the skills gap and are doing something about it children need skills that can be used in the workplace and the diploma is designed to provide handson training as a stepping stone into work employers have some work to do too says john arnold chartered occupational psychologist at loughborough university business school its all very well employers saying graduates dont understand the workplace but how would any of them fare in a student culture he asks older and more established workers have their own motives to notice what younger people cant do they may feel threatened by them for more information visit millionorguk

text: geeks and feminists have much in common if feminism is about embracing and striving for some kind of utopian dream of human equality then democratising knowledge is an important part of this process increasingly new technologies and information and communication technologies in particular have huge potential to democratise access to creation of and distribution of knowledge theres an important distinction here between information and knowledge knowledge involves some kind of engagement with processing of and ownership of information participatory video for example is changing the way people do research allowing researchers and activists to work with rural communities in new and innovative ways enabling these communities to shape the ways in which they are represented and understood not only can communities more actively connect with and influence the research process they can also more readily access key research findings without having to wade through mountains of heavy academic text for academics and activists involved in policy processes this entirely changes the field and brings new voices including those of poorer women into the debate digital storytelling is another specific methodology being used not just to extract information from people or to build evidence for arguments but to also allow people to tell their own story on their terms participants come up with a threeminute audio narrative which they illustrate with chosen imagery for anyone who has had experience of this process there is no denying the transformative power of opening up spaces for peoples voices to be heard and taken seriously then theres the added bonus of creating something beautiful from the process i was recently at a feminist technology exchange ftx run as part of and in the lead up to the association of womens rights in development ftx was developed in response to calls from feminist and womens rights movements for greater understanding of emerging technologies their potential and impact on the rights and lives of women what ftx emphasised was the importance for feminists of accessing and creating information in the context of very specific activist struggles the ramifications of this are clear for example the project that gives survivors of domestic violence untraceable donated cell phones to ensure secure communication when they are seeking help or the project that uses mobile phones to update people about what hivaids treatment should be available to them in their area these new technologies films mobile phones the internet are particularly useful when working with previously marginalised groups because they offer an instant global platform and when working with vulnerable groups because they offer speed of information transfer and anonymity much of the expression of lesbian and gay identity particularly in the africa the middle east and asia for example happens online where people are relatively protected by the anonymity afforded by the internet however there are other arenas of struggle which although perhaps more subtle are arguably as important how for example do images of different women in different contexts shape the way we view the world in terms of what we imagine exists and in terms of what we imagine can exist one example is a film made by colleagues in bangladesh which shows women doing jobs traditionally regarded as mens work many people have responded with a mixture of surprise and awe often it has never occurred to them that it would be possible for women to occupy such roles a strong argument for encouraging a more democratic use of media technologies is that it will enable us to change the way in which women are popularly represented in particular in the global south we need more images of women that challenge popular orthodoxies and narratives images of for example barefoot pregnant african women reinforce unnuanced negative stereotypes of woman as victims by ensuring women have access to these technologies we can populate the media with grassroots knowledge and cultural artefacts from new perspectives whats interesting about the use of information and communication technologies is not just the creation of these new artefacts and the ways they are influencing change but the process of their creation and the potential for the traditionally structurally disempowered to be in control of and understand the creation tools all this is good news for the left and for those interested in cultural politics george lakoff an american sociolinguist influential in contemporary debates about revitalising progressive politics argues that we need to carefully reframe the way in which we articulate social policy issues in order to effectively communicate a more democratic approach to knowledge creation and distribution should allow us to be a lot more aware of the way in which we speak about issues and the metaphors we invoke in so doing artful use of information and communication strategies can reengage the popular imagination empower the disenfranchised and reclaim political discourse tessa lewin is the communication and learning officer for the pathways of womens empowerment research programme consortium

text: you dont have to be poor to experience domestic violence plenty of middleclass women and some men are beaten and humiliated by their partners but theres growing evidence that the global recession is making people more vulnerable to physical and mental abuse this isnt because poverty causes violence in itself but it does create conditions a sudden change in circumstances acute financial problems loss of selfesteem in which its likely to take place in an interview in the guardian today attorney general baroness scotland says she believes domestic violence will become more widespread as the recession deepens which supports reports from the us where the effects of the subprime crisis began to be felt a while ago putting families under huge levels of stress a recent report from florida suggests that domestic violence refuges in tampa bay are struggling to cope with an increase in the numbers of women seeking a safe place to stay one refuge took in women in october this year twice as many as the same period last year obviously there is no excuse for domestic violence and many men who suffer a sudden drop in income or lose their jobs dont take it out on their partners and children but preexisting abuse is likely to get worse if a man is angry depressed and spending more time at home because he no longer has a job men who feel insecure often abuse their partners and children to make themselves feel less inadequate as a recent editorial in the british medical journal acknowledged violence is used frequently to resolve a crisis of male identity it observed it also pointed out that poverty increases vulnerability by raising the degree of conflict in relationships diminishing womens economic power and reducing mens ability to lead what they think of as successful lives amnesty international which has run a highprofile campaign against domestic violence around the world sees poverty and marginalisation as both causes and consequences of violence against women poor women in developing countries find it harder to escape abusive situations get protection from violent partners or redress from the criminal justice system this is particularly true when women are illiterate and live in countries where patriarchal attitudes persist among lawyers and judges in the developed world decades of campaigning by organisations such as refuge mean that the existence of domestic violence is widely acknowledged but the impact of the recession on already fraught relationships is only just being recognised as unemployment and job insecurity affects more families its depressing but not surprising that women are becoming scapegoats for their partners feelings of anger and humiliation job losses are being reported daily and men who have lost their own incomes may resent the fact that their partners are still working even if theyre in minimum wage jobs or they may drink to blot out their misery exacerbating financial problems and making violence more likely as economic forecasts for the next year get worse the government needs to alert gps teachers and social workers to look for signs of abuse in those families hit hardest by the recession

text: one in four parents have reduced their working life to spend more time with their family according to a government study that also charts the rise of relay parenting whereby mums and dads parent in shifts to fit around their jobs families are under stress from the pressures of juggling work and home life but even so parents who work are more likely to stay together because financial problems are one of the biggest strains a relationship can suffer says the wideranging cabinet office study which documents the changing nature of families it was presented at a conference of newspaper and tv agony aunts convened by the childrens secretary ed balls to highlight the impact of family breakdown on children the paper declares the end of the typical family we see an increasing range of family structures to the extent that there is arguably no longer a onesizefitsall family in britain today but this is diversity and not decline warm loving and stable relationships matter more for our happiness and wellbeing than the legal form of a relationship says the introduction written by the minister for families beverley hughes and the cabinet office minister liam byrne it documents the growing impact of working lives on families around of adults aged to have downshifted their careers over the last years by quitting their jobs reducing their hours or changing their career path a third said spending more time with their family was the primary reason nearly were looking for a more fulfilling job and about said they were looking for a postmaterialist lifestyle while mothers and fathers now spend more quality time with their children in particular taking part in educational activities there is much less couple time for parents children see less of their parents as a couple stability as possible they can ameliorate those damaging effects families that experience breakdown face the most challenges but a negative impact on their children is not inevitable maternal text: who is best placed to bring up your child you or the possibly transient probably underpaid young and not as naturally qualified staff of a daycare centre this is the question raised by last weeks report from unicef on the state of childcare in developed countries for the first time in centuries it notes the majority of parents in the developed world are farming out the care of their children to paid workers at the same time neuroscientific research shows surprise surprise that the architecture of the brain is formed largely through the interactions of the early years love it turns out is as important for intellectual as for emotional development so this mothering thing that my generation was taught to disdain as something we could fit in round our economically valuable highstatus real work and that we could get away with paying other people low wages to do proves to be not such a side issue after all women have always known this secretly of course since childcare has been our historic responsibility weve felt in dereliction of our duty when we were on maternity leave or doing more of the childcare because that was how the architecture of our own brains had been established we could see how much social capital was created by meeting other parents hanging around at school gates this awkward truth remains the great unspoken issue of the childcare debate feminists dont particularly want to face it publicly because it plays into the hands of reactionaries whod rather we werent in the workplace and certainly not competing for the top jobs unfortunately theres another unpalatable reality in conflict with that one being with children all the time can be boring draining and frustrating most women work not only because they couldnt otherwise manage financially but also because work offers selfesteem sociability power and dignity the trouble with paid childcare is that it lets men off the hook women have to pay for childcare because most men arent prepared to cut back their hours to do enough of the parenting if women want to work it should be men rather than children who alter their lives it comes as no real surprise then that the countries doing best in unicefs assessment are those with the most social and gender equality sweden and iceland in the uk the debate about whether to opt for paid childcare in what form and how much of it takes place against a background of growing inequality a winnertakesall society where not to be constantly available on your blackberry is not to have a proper career the rewards for work of often opaque value certainly compared to raising a child can be enormous extended parental leave job security and parttime employment are for wimps many women look at the pay gap at their own inclination to balance at the impossibility of two parents being distracted most of the time and choose to work parttime or at any rate with less zealotry and most parents manage to cobble something together that more or less works the unicef report is flawed in not taking into account informal homebased or neighbourhood childcare grandparents child minders au pairs parents may feel guilty about how much of their childrens upbringing they delegate to others but the dangerous experiment that unicef implies we are embarked upon is actually being pursued for the most part with love and concern for the balance of everyones interests which is not to say that the circumstances in which the decisions are being made are remotely ideal it is those who arent in a position to make decisions with whom we should really be concerned one reason britain figured so poorly on unicefs rankings the government disputes our midtable position is that there are still three million children living in poverty here many are clustered in places where the notion of family itself seems to have collapsed here it is not a choice of whether both parents have serious jobs because theres only one parent and no work these families feature a desire to do the best by children as do families everywhere but have little ballast in terms of work or structure to lives a child from the most disadvantaged per cent of families is times more likely to have multiple problems at the age of than a child from the most affluent per cent of families nursery care can be invaluable here the unicef report which does rather lack the courage of its alarmist convictions acknowledges that daycare can improve linguistic and social development and help break the cycle of deprivation if you wanted to design an ideal emmeline had been the leader of the british suffragette movement and arguably the godmother of the battle for womens rights so it was drilled into us from an early age that much of what we had as girls and the opportunities we would be granted as women our schooling career opportunities the vote access to contraception and more had been fought for we were not to take anything for granted yet inevitably as we grew up through the s and then s that is exactly what we began to do after all to us the notion that girls should be treated any differently to boys in terms of education or that women should not have equality in the workplace or be barred from the political process seemed absurd we had never watched these issues being fought over we were born into a world where many had already been won and with so many battles behind us it is little surprise that the rate of change appears to have slowed down in my lifetime i am the womens rights movement seems to have moved forward text: in war when a commander orders the bombing of a strategic target all too often civilians collateral damage bear the brunt sometimes this is by design sometimes not for the more ruthless it is part of a zerosum strategy to humiliate terrorise and disempower the enemy rape as a weapon is just such a terror tactic one that views damaged and traumatised women as merely collateral damage while forcing large numbers of civilians to flee a territory in panic the coordinated mass rape of women is increasingly a weapon of choice not least in the democratic republic of congo as the film released by the guardian today demonstrates little or no action is currently being taken to stop this of course rape is forbidden under international law the customary laws of war forbid attacks on civilians including the rape of women rape is a war crime under the geneva conventions and several other legal codes the rome statute which established the international criminal court provides an extensive definition of rape as a war crime and the tribunals for the former yugoslavia and rwanda have prosecuted rape as a war crime indeed systematic use of rape can also be a crime against humanity and a constitutive element of genocide however the problem is that the laws are hardly adhered to at all to return to just one example among many in the congo a yearold woman called bitondo nyumba a mother of four from katungulu in south kivu province was beaten and raped in her own home by seven government army soldiers in her injuries were so severe that despite two operations she later died although this was not an unusual case the difference was that her family launched a campaign to bring the perpetrators to justice against the odds they were successful three men were pronounced guilty by a military tribunal in uvira in september this year but it was a hollow victory they remained untouched continuing to serve in their regiment meanwhile congo was about to plunge into a new bout of anarchy creating yet more cases like bitondo nyumbas what is the international community to do in the face of this horrific reality robust peacekeeping and serious engagement from major powers not least the african union is obviously key but so too is dealing with the aftermath of mass rape in june the un security council agreed resolution establishing not only that the use of rape as a systematic weapon of war is a war crime but that failure to prosecute and provide redress prolongs deepens and reignites conflict possibly a statement of the obvious its nevertheless an important recognition of the damaging genderviolence spiral that a conflict can create and it couldnt be more relevant to congo congos decade of violence derives from a horrible multiplicity of causal factors the tailend of genocide and ethnic hatred greed for minerals and land congolese political implosion and foreign intervention and one spark to the flame has been the overwhelming sense that killers and rapists were going to get away with it noone was going to bring them to justice ever as in so many conflicts women and children have borne the brunt of suffering in congo amnesty recently published a report showing that for every two child soldiers rescued from the north kivu conflict five more are abducted and forced to serve as soldiers and rape is used to a terrifying extent at the end of the un records that rape cases were being reported every month in north kivu province alone how is this impacting on communities first husbands of female rape victims often seem to find it harder to cope with the rape than the women themselves rejection and ostracism is common women just have to pick up the pieces and rebuild their and their childrens lives and often also rebuild their own communities meanwhile un efforts to deal with the aftermath of conflict and mass rape are still in development for example un security council resolution passed at the turn of this century after much lobbying by womens rights activists around the world requires all peace and reconstruction processes to put gender at their heart in liberia for example attempts have been made to make resolution projects work but in practice theyve often foundered the un has offered disarmament and rehabilitation programmes to excombatants of whom had been women in liberias wars of the s and s but as they were designed with men in mind the women often couldnt benefit locations and hours of courses made them inaccessible for many women and no childcare support was offered indeed many women wouldnt even present to the programmes as this meant identifying themselves as rape survivors and excombatants and exposing themselves to shame stigma and hostility the un has hopefully learnt from where it went wrong in liberia what we need are projects women set up themselves designed around the realities of womens needs these have proven relatively sustainable in liberia producing tangible economic benefits to the whole community perhaps when people do get round the table to rebuild conflictravaged african countries the un will give better force to its own resolutions and have women at the discussion with their own solutions for a truly lasting peace and economic redevelopment meanwhile how long before the women of congo are able to do this

text: unmarried fathers have reasons to celebrate the welfare reform bill announced in the queens speech proposes new requirements for the birth registration of children each year children are registered with only one parents name on the birth certificate a father who is not named does not have parental responsibility in law and so in theory has no say in a childs upbringing and all the issues that matter such as education and medical treatment in june a white paper recording responsibility explained how joint birth registration would become a legal requirement for all unmarried parents unless the registrar thought it to be impossible impracticable or unreasonable the white paper said mothers would also have a right to insist that the father acknowledges his responsibilities to his child and that the father has a new right to insist that he is registered why does it matter the change has been prompted by the fragile families study in the us carried out to provide information about unmarried parents and their children over several years children three quarters of whom were born to unmarried parents in cities have been followed to look at what keeps a couple together and what tears them apart the study looked in detail at issues such as the capabilities potential and realised of fathers in particular how the children fare and what policies help or hinder in the process the fragile families has usefully helped to bin a number of stereotypes including that of the disengaged deadbeat dad given a chance often signalled by joint birth registration men do try to do the right thing the study found most fathers appear to be very involved and to be committed to helping raise the child even among unmarried fathers and even among fathers who are not residing with the mothers in the uk as the white paper pointed out drawing on the fragile families findings a fathers positive involvement in a childs life can lead to good educational achievement and reduce the risk of mental health issues for children in separated families it can also help to boost a childs resilience and wellbeing some critics oppose the idea of joint registration saying it might put some mothers and children at risk of an abusive dad asserting his rights to the detriment of all the fragile families study indicated that unmarried mothers sometimes do struggle between wanting a fathers involvement with their child and the need to protect the child from violence andor substance misuse the study said mothers distinguish between healthy and unhealthy relationships particularly in cases of domestic violence choosing to end their romantic relationships and limit fathers access to the children the study also recommended that different options should be found to incarceration because the impact on children of sending fathers to prison was especially hard more support should also be given to helping families to stay together while trying to tackle issues such as both parents addiction while changes are underway fatherhood is still treated too often as an undertaking on the margins of family life two weeks paternity leave on a pittance underlines that point more engagement of fathers in pregnancy a friend whose wife is expecting a baby imminently says hes constantly made to feel an irritant by the midwives and his view isnt untypical an assumption on the part of gps teachers and nursery staff that father and mother are jointly involved in rearing a child would make a big difference and especially so for young men who want to do their best and yet are treated as if they can only do their worst signing on the dotted line soon after birth gives a dad a better chance of seeing his child grow up well with him but a lot more help is still required to bring fathers in from the frozen wastes of poor expectations

text: the worlds attention always hungry for the pornography of disaster is moving on from the insurgency in the democratic republic of the congo cholera in zimbabwe is this weeks crisis next week it will be another country another tragedy yet in congo as we report today the troubles were claiming victims long before the worlds attention first swooped in september and will go on claiming victims far into the future since biblical times rape has been the final humiliation for defeated populations terrorising families and keeping fearful women from working in the fields or going into the forests to gather wood commonly victims of rape suffer further abuse they are excluded from their community robbed not only of selfworth and often their children but even of the means to feed themselves meanwhile the perpetrators are rarely caught and if they are brought to trial have fled long before they are convicted at best they will receive a derisory prison sentence over the past six months leah chishugi a survivor of the rwanda massacre and now a nurse in the uk has courageously recorded the stories of hundreds of congolese rape victims in kivu province her film is on our website the act of witness is an important start to be taken seriously and treated as an individual is the beginning of the process of restoring some sense of selfworth working to stop these rapes happening in the future is the next step on monday at a specially convened session the un human rights council expressly condemned sexual violence in kivu it called on the government in kinshasa to act but there was no parallel commitment to end the culture of impunity among the militia commanders they must realise that they cannot rape or allow their men to rape free from the fear of consequences that means bolstering the court system and supporting women to bring charges it also means vetting the security services so that rapists and suspected rapists are excluded it means putting womens rights at the heart of peacekeeping and reconstruction and supporting the efforts of local and international charities to provide medical and psychological care for victims but it is also important to begin to understand the pathology of sexual violence in warzones rape can be a weapon of control for the young soldiers who make up the militias often little more than children themselves brutalised by their commanders and seeking however fleetingly to control their environment that means providing schooling and skills for them and for the children born from rape otherwise they will become the next generation of soldiers and the next generation of rapists

text: equality bill the new equality bill aims to consolidate the numerous laws on equality currently standing at nine existing major pieces of legislation and almost other statutory instruments to establish a single body of law public bodies will be under an obligation to consider diversity issues in developing their employment policies and planning services an example given in proposals last year in response to a consultation was that local authorities should consider culturally diverse menus such as kosher and halal options when contracting suppliers for its meals on wheels services the bill will aim to end age discrimination which is likely to have particularly significant implications for healthcare new transparency rules will require public bodies to publish information relating to inequality including the gender pay gap although significant controversy remains about how those are to be measured the bill abolishes the use of secrecy clauses by public bodies which prevent employees uncovering gender pay gaps by discussing their pay the bill also contains provisions for positive discrimination permitting political parties to use allwomen election shortlists until although it does not go so far as to provide for allethnic minority shortlists positive action will however be extended allowing employers to take into account gender and ethnicity when selecting between two equally qualified candidates afua hirsch legal affairs correspondent constitutional renewal when the government is accused of riding roughshod over the primacy of parliament it would point to the constitutional renewal bill as evidence that it is trying to hand power back to the legislature this weeks arrest of an mp and civil servant might then make the bill even more politically urgent but today the queen said only that the government would continue to take forward proposals on constitutional renewal the government said the bill would only be introduced when time allows the ministry of justice indicated that would be in the new year the putative bill has already been dismissed as a ragbag of retreats by some of those mps on select committee responsible for scrutinising the bill in their view botching the reform of the dual legal and political roles of the attorney general critics want them separated as an attempt to depoliticise the attorney role in sensitive cases such as the legal status of the invasion of iraq in its current state some mps believed the attorney generals office might be afforded more power after the passage of this bill other measures included the setting up of an independent commission for the civil service which will define the role and values of the civil service in law protecting them against being undermined by the government this bill would also have ensured that the ratification of treaties must be voted on by parliament allegra stratton political parties and elections bill carried over from the last session beefs up electoral commission the elections watchdog allows greater scrutiny of donations particularly from foreign sources and limits spending by candidates to between elections will woodward
